name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/40461"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=40461"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=40461"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=40461"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=40461"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=40461"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2621747,"date":"2023-10-30T10:34:22","date_gmt":"2023-10-30T17:34:22","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2621747"},"modified":"2023-10-30T13:59:36","modified_gmt":"2023-10-30T20:59:36","slug":"chatgpt-for-career-growth-practica-introduces-ai-based-career-coaching-and-mentorship","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/30\/chatgpt-for-career-growth-practica-introduces-ai-based-career-coaching-and-mentorship\/","title":{"rendered":"ChatGPT for career growth? Practica introduces AI-based career coaching and mentorship"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Can an AI be your mentor? That’s what a startup called "https:\/\/practicahq.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Practica<\/a> believes. The company, which evolved out of a marketplace for one-on-one executive coaching, has now launched an AI system built on top of an existing knowledge base it developed over the years spent with a large group of human coaches. The resulting AI chatbot experience functions as a personalized workplace mentor and coach that can aid professionals in bettering their skills across a dozen different topics, including management, strategy, sales, personal development, growth, customer success, marketing, data, design, finance and more.<\/p>\n Originally co-founded in January 2020 by "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/davewhittemore\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Dave Whittemore<\/a>, former Thinkful head of Product (which "https:\/\/news.crunchbase.com\/business\/in-its-largest-deal-yet-chegg-acquires-online-coding-school-thinkful-for-80m\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">exited to Chegg<\/a>), and former Dropbox engineering manager "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/andy-scheff-5a0b4256\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Andy Scheff<\/a>, Practica initially tackled the problem around continuous upskilling throughout your career with a traditional executive coaching marketplace.<\/p>\n “We both became executive coaches,” explains Whittemore. “Andy and I both plunged ourselves into it…I coached product managers and Andy coached engineers,” he says.<\/p>\n Later that year, the site grew by adding a marketplace for other executive coaches, and today it still offers 250 human coaches across domain-specific expertise. Indeed, 90% of that business is B2B — that is, selling Practica’s services to employers. That business is also now profitable on an operating basis.<\/p>\n However, the founders realized that pricing prevented people from being able to access its services.<\/p>\n "attachment_2621820\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2621820\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2621820\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-3@2x.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"445\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-3@2x.png 1560w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-3@2x.png?resize=150,98 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-3@2x.png?resize=300,196 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-3@2x.png?resize=768,502 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-3@2x.png?resize=680,445 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-3@2x.png?resize=1536,1004 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-3@2x.png?resize=1200,785 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-3@2x.png?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2621820\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Practica<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n “The average per-hour price was $200 an hour and the per-hour price varied based on the seniority level of the person being coached and the coach…If you got coached for the full year, the average person who does a full year of coaching spends about $3,000 a year,” Whittemore said. “That price is the barrier, and that’s what led us to AI coaching,” he adds.<\/p>\n The idea was to take what they had learned through personal one-on-one coaching and blend that together with AI technology. Over the years, they had learned what makes coaching relationships successful and that helped them understand what kind of constructs to build around and on top of an LLM. Their knowledge base consists of a large number of publicly available learning materials, ranging from blog posts to conference talks to videos to podcasts to books and more, which have been hand-picked and curated into hundreds of different skills across a variety of topics.<\/p>\n "attachment_2621816\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2621816\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2621816\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-1@2x.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"445\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-1@2x.png 1560w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-1@2x.png?resize=150,98 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-1@2x.png?resize=300,196 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-1@2x.png?resize=768,502 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-1@2x.png?resize=680,445 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-1@2x.png?resize=1536,1004 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-1@2x.png?resize=1200,785 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/practica-screenshot-1@2x.png?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2621816\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Practica<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Of course, many websites today are now blocking AI web crawlers, as they don’t want to be aggregated into AI chatbot experiences. So we asked if there was a concern that some of these sites where the materials were found would do the same. But unlike ChatGPT or some other AI chatbots, Practica says it’s focused on pushing its users out to the sources where the content comes from, not just providing answers. This results in increased traffic for the publisher or content provider it indexes and references.<\/p>\n That said, the company has not yet made any formal licensing arrangements with its educational source providers — some of which could be as simple as a helpful blog post from an engineer, or someone writing about how they overcame challenges as a manager.<\/p>\n In addition, in terms of the AI models under the hood, the goal is to be vendor-agnostic and only focus on the application layer on top of that — which means Practica isn’t directly competing with companies like OpenAI or Google, but rather capable of working with them.<\/p>\n To coach its professional users, the company uses a technique called Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) to match the best learning resources for the situation a given learner is in, the team tells TechCrunch. The AI coach explains what’s in the sources it retrieved and why they’re helpful — just as a human coach would. It cites the sources and encourages the user to go and read them as “homework.”<\/p>\n Practica’s use of third-party content, then, is more of a curated search engine, rather than machine learning model training. But the AI is doing the coaching.<\/p>\n That part of the AI’s methodology mixes together a number of coaching tools, including instruction, questioning for context, finding present challenges in the learner\u2019s job to use as learning materials, mapping learning progress to the learner\u2019s career goals, and celebrating wins along the way. It finds the appropriate material, organizes the insights from those materials into a list that the user can interact with, and adds notes you can reference later.<\/p>\n Plus, unlike today’s generalized AI chatbots, Practica’s AI remembers the learner’s history so it can build on their skills as they continue to use the service.<\/p>\n “You can have generalized system instructions, but it’s not really memorizing what it needs to know about you from one session to the next,” says Whittemore, comparing Practica to general-purpose AI chatbots. “We try to be very intentional about that…we remember how you’ve been developing over time so that we can continue to coach really well — the same way a human coach would.”<\/p>\n The system has been in private testing since July of this year and is now opening up to individual learners for between $10 to $20 per month per user. (A “teams” version from employers is also in limited testing.)<\/p>\n At this price point, Practica hopes to make executive coaching more accessible.<\/p>\n “We’re optimistic that it’s actually going to expand executive coaching,” says Whittmore. “Our hope is that we get to get more people touching this at the AI coaching level, and learning about how effective executive coaching is and therefore upgrading to the premium product,” he says, referring to the company’s human coaching services.<\/p>\n Practica has raised $1.5 million in outside funding from across two rounds in 2021 and 2022, before it shifted into AI-based coaching. Both rounds were led by Script Capital and included over 40 individual angel investors, many of whom were leaders in the domains where the company focuses its coaching.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Can an AI be your mentor? That’s what a startup called Practica believes. The company, which evolved out of a marketplace for one-on-one executive coaching, has now launched an AI system built on top of an existing knowledge base it developed over the years spent with a large group of human coaches. The resulting AI […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":2414667,"featured_media":2621818,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"ba850d34-4b34-38a3-9fcf-60d10766b824","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-30T17:34:31Z","apple_news_api_id":"07212bf8-78f1-4678-8691-f8621be4740d","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-30T20:55:38Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAg==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AByEr-HjxRniGkfhiG-R0DQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203,577051039,20429],"tags":[14067,576740803,12374,13926,576649331,304144,164094,576914672],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n ChatGPT for career growth? :\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/30\/chatgpt-app-revenue-shows-no-signs-of-slowing-but-some-other-ai-apps-top-it\/","title":{"rendered":"ChatGPT app revenue shows no signs of slowing, but some other AI apps top it"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/17\/chatgpt-everything-to-know-about-the-ai-chatbot\/\">ChatGPT<\/a>, the AI-powered chatbot from OpenAI, far outpaces all other AI chatbot apps on mobile devices in terms of downloads and is a market leader by revenue, as well. However, it’s surprisingly not the top AI app by revenue — several photo AI apps and even other AI chatbots are actually making more money than ChatGPT, despite the latter having become a household name for an AI chat experience.<\/p>\n Since "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/18\/openai-launches-an-official-chatgpt-app-for-ios\/\">its launch on mobile devices<\/a> in May of this year, ChatGPT’s downloads and revenue have continued to grow. In its first month, when the app was available on iOS only, it topped 3.9 million downloads, which grew to 15.1 million by June, according to an analysis of the AI app market by "http:\/\/apptopia.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Apptopia<\/a>. Then, following a slight dip in July, ChatGPT grew again to top 23 million downloads as of September 2023.<\/p>\n In addition, ChatGPT’s usage on mobile devices has similarly grown from just over 1.34 million monthly active users in May to now 38.88 million as of September.<\/p>\n Perhaps even more importantly, ChatGPT’s mobile app is outpacing much of the AI chatbot market by consumer spending, which grew from $352,929 during the month of its launch to reach $1.98 million as of September and nearly $2.39 million as of October 24, where the current data set ends.<\/p>\n But it’s not the top app by revenue in the AI chatbot space. “Chat & Ask AI” and “ChatOn — AI Chat Bot Assistant” both pulled in more money in September at nearly $3.38 million and $2.11 million, respectively. Other apps are also close on ChatGPT’s heels with “AI Chatbot — Nova” and “AI Chatbot: AI Chat Smith” pulling in nearly $1.44 million and $1.72 million in September, respectively.<\/p>\n As ChatGPT has a lot of competition for users’ time on mobile, there are now at least five AI chatbot apps that have topped 2 million downloads in September, including several generically named apps like “Chat & Ask AI,” “ChatOn — AI Chat Bot Assistant,” “AI Chatbot — Nova,” and “AI Chatbot: AI Chat Smith” with 2.44 million, 2.02 million, 3.1 million, and 2.9 million downloads, respectively. These apps appear to be capitalizing on App Store SEO — meaning they’re ranking well for terms users might search for, like “AI Chat” and the like. While that’s still far short of ChatGPT’s 23 million last month, it does demonstrate a market for AI apps that extends beyond OpenAI’s creation.<\/p>\n In addition, the a16z-backed chatbot startup Character.ai, which allows users to interact with and create their own AI personas, is in the running with 2.39 million downloads as of September.<\/p>\n "attachment_2551165\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2551165\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2551165\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/05\/characterai-Mobile-App.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"334\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/05\/characterai-Mobile-App.png 1011w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/05\/characterai-Mobile-App.png?resize=150,74 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/05\/characterai-Mobile-App.png?resize=300,147 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/05\/characterai-Mobile-App.png?resize=768,378 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/05\/characterai-Mobile-App.png?resize=680,334 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/05\/characterai-Mobile-App.png?resize=50,25 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2551165\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Character.AI<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n What’s more, many AI chatbot apps also have an active user base. For instance, Poe, the chatbot app from the Q&A site Quora, had over 1.18 million monthly active users (MAUs) as of September, compared with ChatGPT’s nearly 39 million.<\/p>\n The generic apps have a following — meaning they’re not just buying downloads, they’re also retaining their users. “Chat & Ask AI” had 9.7 million MAUs in September, “ChatOn — AI Chat Bot Assistant” had 3.5 million MAUs, followed by “Genie — AI Chatbot AI Assistant” (2.3 million), “AI Chat — Chatbot AI Assistant” (2.17 million), “AI Chatbot — Nova” (8.55 million), and “AI Chatbot: AI Chat Smith” (8.48 million). Character.ai also had 5.92 million monthly active users that month.<\/p>\n Then there are the AI photo apps which use AI technologies for editing effects, or for personalized images of yourself.<\/p>\n "attachment_2572236\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2572236\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2572236\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/remini-app-ios.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"Remini icon\" width=\"680\" height=\"382\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/remini-app-ios.jpg 1796w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/remini-app-ios.jpg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/remini-app-ios.jpg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/remini-app-ios.jpg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/remini-app-ios.jpg?resize=680,382 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/remini-app-ios.jpg?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/remini-app-ios.jpg?resize=1200,675 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/07\/remini-app-ios.jpg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2572236\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Remini<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Though operating in an adjacent space to ChatGPT, some of these apps are giving the AI assistant a run for its money across metrics like downloads, usage and in-app purchase revenue.<\/p>\n With 23 million downloads in September, ChatGPT still leads the pack, but apps that go viral — like “Remini” — have come close- ish<\/em> to ChatGPT’s installs. “Remini,” for example, topped 16.17 million downloads last month, months after "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/20\/remini-tops-the-app-store-for-its-viral-ai-headshots-but-its-body-edits-go-too-far-some-say\/\">its AI headshots feature blew up on TikTok<\/a>. “PicsArt AI Photo Editor” also had a solid September with nearly 16.05 million installs.<\/p>\n “Remini” also topped 6.2 million monthly users last month, while “FaceApp,” which includes some AI filters, had more than 6.4 million. Other apps including “PicsArt” (4.27 million MAUs), “Wonder — AI Art Generator” (4.77 million MAUs) and “Facetune AI Photo\/Video Editor” (5.22 million MAUs) were seeing high usage, too.<\/p>\n Quite a few AI photo apps are attracting greater revenue via in-app purchases, compared with ChatGPT, as well. There could be several factors at play here, however. For starters, ChatGPT also sells its "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/01\/openai-launches-chatgpt-plus-starting-at-20-per-month\/\"> ChatGPT Plus premium subscription<\/a> via the web, where many people use the chatbot assistant. AI photo apps, meanwhile, often acquire the bulk of their revenue via users’ smartphones as they interact with the photos stored on users’ Camera Roll. Plus, many apps “go viral,” gaining them their 15 minutes of fame, which sometimes extends into longtime usage or ongoing subscriptions as users explore their other features.<\/p>\n While ChatGPT pulled in $1.98 million in mobile consumer spend as of September 2023, apps including “Remini,” “PicsArt,” “Wonder,” “BeautyPlus — AI Photo\/Video Edit,” “FaceApp” and “Facetune: AI Photo\/Video Editor” made more at roughly $6.22 million, $4.27 million, $2.08 million, $4.78 million, $6.42 million and $5.22 million, respectively.<\/p>\n However, the popularity of AI photo apps may be shorter-lived than ChatGPT, in some cases. For instance, Lensa, which went viral last year, had 23.44 million downloads in December 2002. That’s fallen to 413,814 monthly installs as of September 2023 and 739,000 monthly actives, down from nearly 24.9 million in December. It also pulled in $739,000 in mobile consumer spend last month, down from a high of over $24 million, Apptopia’s research finds. While the current numbers are still respectable, they do show there’s a tendency for users to switch between viral AI photo apps after some time as new features are marketed and developed elsewhere.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" ChatGPT, the AI-powered chatbot from OpenAI, far outpaces all other AI chatbot apps on mobile devices in terms of downloads and is a market leader by revenue, as well. However, it’s surprisingly not the top AI app by revenue — several photo AI apps and even other AI chatbots are actually making more money than […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":2414667,"featured_media":2549332,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"aa53c66d-c838-3cdf-a0eb-b8d780855f07","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-30T15:52:46Z","apple_news_api_id":"cddb438e-6b7f-44bc-b96f-bf016521f93f","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-30T19:22:56Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAg==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AzdtDjmt_RLy5b78BZSH5Pw","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203,577051039],"tags":[14067,449557101,12374,577151780,577089886],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577089886"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577089886"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=577089886"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577089886"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=577089886"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577089886"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2621137,"date":"2023-10-27T10:07:39","date_gmt":"2023-10-27T17:07:39","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2621137"},"modified":"2023-10-27T10:29:40","modified_gmt":"2023-10-27T17:29:40","slug":"startup-browser-maker-arc-now-lets-you-share-spaces-folders-and-split-views-with-non-arc-users","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/27\/startup-browser-maker-arc-now-lets-you-share-spaces-folders-and-split-views-with-non-arc-users\/","title":{"rendered":"Startup browser maker Arc now lets you share Spaces, Folders and Split Views with non-Arc users"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\"> "https:\/\/arc.net\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Arc<\/a>, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/25\/arc-browser-is-now-available-to-download-for-everyone\/\">the web browser startup<\/a> that’s convincing some power users to give up Chrome, is now inviting other non-Arc users to test drive its capabilities with the launch of a trio of new “shareable” features. The company this week introduced the ability to share special views, including Spaces, Folders and Split Views with anyone — whether they use the Arc browser or not.<\/p>\n This first experiment in broader sharing could potentially introduce new users to Arc who haven’t yet heard of the browser or had the time to check it out. It also helpfully demonstrates some of the differentiating features that make Arc a unique way to access the internet, research and collect links, and organize your areas of interest.<\/p>\n With Spaces, for example, the idea is to allow you to create separate areas within Arc focused on your personal life or work, or anything else you want to keep in a dedicated area.<\/p>\n For instance, you could have a Space dedicated to a particular hobby or interest, or ongoing research related to a purchase you were planning for a work project, or anything else. Now, you can opt to share one of your Spaces with friends with a new “Share” button accessed by hovering over the Space’s title. The company demonstrated this with a "https:\/\/arc.net\/space\/19F60CFA-CEBC-4BEE-AF13-58360F860855\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> Space dedicated to fall trip ideas<\/a>, which included folders of Halloween costume ideas, apple-picking spots and Airbnb listings.<\/p>\n Users don’t have to install Arc to view your Space’s collection of links — it opens directly in their preferred browser, like Chrome, under a unique URL that begins arc.net\/space.<\/p>\n "attachment_2621156\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2621156\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2621156\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-spaces.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"330\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-spaces.jpg 2756w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-spaces.jpg?resize=150,73 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-spaces.jpg?resize=300,146 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-spaces.jpg?resize=768,373 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-spaces.jpg?resize=680,330 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-spaces.jpg?resize=1536,746 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-spaces.jpg?resize=2048,994 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-spaces.jpg?resize=1200,583 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-spaces.jpg?resize=50,24 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2621156\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Arc<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Similarly, you can organize a collection of links in a dedicated folder to share with others. Unlike Spaces, Arc’s folders are a simpler way to keep a bunch of related tabs together. For example, you could organize a folder of links for a project you’re working on, articles you want to read later, a recipe collection, trip planning links or any other interest. While there is some overlap in use cases between Spaces and Folders, Spaces are more distinct areas that have their own theme and icon. You’re meant to switch between Spaces either by clicking on their icon on the bottom of the Sidebar or move between them with a two-finger swipe on your trackpad. A common use case for Spaces is to have a way to switch between using your browser for work and for your personal life when you’re off the clock.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n With Folders, the Arc team demonstrated the concept of a shareable folder with a "https:\/\/arc.net\/folder\/AFF09F7B-94BC-4D2E-A0DF-727CBF06C0EE\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">list of links for dinner ideas in Honolulu<\/a>. These can also be opened in other browsers via a unique URL that begins arc.net\/folder.<\/p>\n Arc co-founder and CEO Josh Miller noted on X that the Folders and Spaces features would have been useful back when he worked at Thrive Capital as a way to organize the due diligence it was doing on potential investments, as another example.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--twitter\">\n "twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n "en\" dir=\"ltr\">Now you can share Arc Folders & Spaces w your co-workers \u2013 even if they don't use Arc! <\/p>\n When I worked at "https:\/\/twitter.com\/ThriveCapital?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@ThriveCapital<\/a>, I would've created a new Arc Folder for each company we were doing diligence on. And then share a single (Arc Folder) link in Slack as bundle of all my work! "https:\/\/t.co\/uHEyTAOWBk\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pic.twitter.com\/uHEyTAOWBk<\/a><\/p>\n — Josh Miller (@joshm) "https:\/\/twitter.com\/joshm\/status\/1717631509975159289?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">October 26, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n Meanwhile, the third new shareable feature is Split view. As it sounds, Split view is a multi-tasking view that lets you view up to four tabs in one window, which can help if you need to view multiple browser tabs at the same time — like when referencing a project file or your calendar schedule when composing an email, for instance. Or you could simply use it for fun, by having work items paired alongside a distraction — like an online game of Wordle, for when you needed to take a break.<\/p>\n Arc showed off a shareable Split View with "https:\/\/company.us6.list-manage.com\/track\/click?u=73c2f0478f1b3cd8343ae8f45&id=2d55a8a8d2&e=672ca94a47\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a collection of links that showcase design inspirations.<\/a> Again, these URLs begin arc.net and are then followed by \/split and a unique identifier.<\/p>\n "attachment_2621155\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2621155\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2621155 size-large\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-split-view.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"341\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-split-view.jpg 2750w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-split-view.jpg?resize=150,75 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-split-view.jpg?resize=300,150 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-split-view.jpg?resize=768,385 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-split-view.jpg?resize=680,341 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-split-view.jpg?resize=1536,770 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-split-view.jpg?resize=2048,1026 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-split-view.jpg?resize=1200,601 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/arc-split-view.jpg?resize=50,25 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2621155\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Arc<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Founded by\u00a0Branch co-founders and former Facebook employees\u00a0 "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/josh-miller-b31259106\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/josh-miller-b31259106\/\">Josh Miller<\/a>\u00a0and\u00a0 "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/hurshagrawal\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/hurshagrawal\/\">Hursh Agrawal<\/a> in 2019, Arc raised its first outside capital in 2021, with "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/14\/chrome-competitor-the-browser-company-quietly-raises-5m\/\">a $5 million investment<\/a> from angels including LinkedIn\u2019s Jeff Weiner, Medium\u2019s Ev Williams and Figma\u2019s Dylan Field, among others. The browser "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/25\/arc-browser-is-now-available-to-download-for-everyone\/\">itself opened to the public this July.<\/a><\/p>\n Though Arc has its advocates, they tend to be web power users, who are looking for more bells and whistles from their browser. Arc delivers that, along with a fully redesigned browser experience where its tabs and the search bar are off to the side. There’s also a bevy of keyboard shortcuts to navigate its features and capabilities. But that also means Arc has a bit of a steep learning curve for newcomers, as it’s trying to be very<\/em> different<\/em> from traditional browsers, in addition to adding new functionality. The shareable features could potentially offer users a new way to experience Arc, without having to fully commit to making the switch.<\/p>\n Ahead of this launch, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/03\/arc-browsers-new-ai-powered-features-combine-openai-and-anthropics-models\/\">Arc also added AI-powered features<\/a> that combine OpenAI and Anthropic’s models in a race to keep up with the AI features offered by Big Tech rivals, Google and Microsoft.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"VjmYtXjJUX\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/03\/arc-browsers-new-ai-powered-features-combine-openai-and-anthropics-models\/\">Arc browser’s new AI-powered features combine OpenAI and Anthropic’s models<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Arc browser’s new AI-powered features combine OpenAI and Anthropic’s models” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/03\/arc-browsers-new-ai-powered-features-combine-openai-and-anthropics-models\/embed\/#?secret=mYBn7MSjtG#?secret=VjmYtXjJUX\" data-secret=\"VjmYtXjJUX\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"m4vcARDVJu\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/25\/arc-browser-is-now-available-to-download-for-everyone\/\">Arc browser is now available to download for everyone<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/5497"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=5497"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=5497"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=5497"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=5497"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=5497"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2621039,"date":"2023-10-27T08:13:00","date_gmt":"2023-10-27T15:13:00","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2621039"},"modified":"2023-10-27T09:57:02","modified_gmt":"2023-10-27T16:57:02","slug":"x-to-take-on-newswire-services-with-new-product-xwire","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/27\/x-to-take-on-newswire-services-with-new-product-xwire\/","title":{"rendered":"X to take on newswire services with new product, XWire"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">As Instagram "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/11\/instagram-head-says-threads-is-not-going-to-amplify-news-on-the-platform\/\">Threads is leaning away from news<\/a>, according to statements made by Instagram head Adam Mosseri, its competitor X appears to be doubling down. Executives at the company formerly known as Twitter spoke during yesterday’s all-hands internal meeting of their desire to create a new wire service called XWire, according to "https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2023-10-27\/musk-tells-x-staff-new-products-will-challenge-youtube-linkedin?sref=gni836kR\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Bloomberg<\/a>. The product would rival existing services for press releases, like Cision’s PR Newswire.<\/p>\n The all-hands on Thursday was the first that both X owner Elon Musk and CEO Linda Yaccarino attended together, after "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/12\/elon-musk-appoints-new-twitter-ceo-nbcus-linda-yaccarino\/\">her hiring in May<\/a>. On the call, the execs touched on a number of initiatives planned for the company, including Musk’s well-known desire to shift X to become an “everything app,” which focuses on creators, video, payments and even hosting users’ money and securities on its platform.<\/p>\n The company also set its sights on competitors like YouTube and LinkedIn in terms of both video and hiring. On the latter front, X recently introduced a jobs listing service, advertised through the @XHiring account, which allows companies to post available positions directly on X through special “job cards” that detail the role, description and other job specifics. This already challenges LinkedIn’s hiring business, but adoption of the feature on X remains small-scale for the time being. The execs didn’t share additional information on how X would better compete with LinkedIn’s business, but tying into other areas where companies distribute their news, as with press releases, could possibly help.<\/p>\n The company shared other milestones during the meeting, including its reach of half a billion posts per day and 100 billion impressions per day — metrics that were "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/04\/actually-x-sees-500m-posts-per-day-not-100m-200m-as-musk-recently-said\/\">previously confirmed to TechCrunch<\/a> after being announced by Yaccarino in an interview at a Khanference 2023 event in October. And in a subsequent blog post, Yaccarino wrote that overall, users spend 7.8 billion active minutes every day and that "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/27\/a-year-after-musks-takeover-x-says-an-average-user-spends-32-minutes-per-day-on-the-platform\/\">an average user spends 32 minutes on the platform<\/a> — numbers that differ slightly from "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/despite-usage-declines-x-remains-stickier-than-first-thought\/\">recent third-party estimates<\/a> focused on U.S. daily active users, who were spending 20.6 minutes on average on the platform as of September.<\/p>\n Do you know more about XWire? Reach out to Sarah at sarahp@techcrunch.com or Signal (415) 234-3994.<\/em><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" As Instagram Threads is leaning away from news, according to statements made by Instagram head Adam Mosseri, its competitor X appears to be doubling down. Executives at the company formerly known as Twitter spoke during yesterday’s all-hands internal meeting of their desire to create a new wire service called XWire, according to Bloomberg. The product name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577202440"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577202440"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=577202440"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577202440"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=577202440"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577202440"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2620586,"date":"2023-10-26T11:08:27","date_gmt":"2023-10-26T18:08:27","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2620586"},"modified":"2023-10-26T16:02:01","modified_gmt":"2023-10-26T23:02:01","slug":"threads-isnt-dead-and-it-now-has-polls-and-gifs-too","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/threads-isnt-dead-and-it-now-has-polls-and-gifs-too\/","title":{"rendered":"Threads isn’t dead and it now has polls and GIFs too"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Meta’s X rival, Instagram Threads, is copying a couple more X features today with the "https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@zuck\/post\/Cy3m1VnRiwP\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">launch of support<\/a> for polls and GIFs. The update comes in rapid succession to other releases for the new app, which have included "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/22\/its-official-threads-launches-its-highly-anticipated-web-app\/\">support for a web version,<\/a> a (free) "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/12\/threads-is-rolling-out-an-edit-button-and-you-dont-have-to-pay-for-it\/\">edit button,<\/a> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/22\/threads-adds-easy-profile-switching-to-its-mobile-apps\/\">profile switching<\/a>, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/08\/06\/threads-app-is-rolling-out-to-a-way-to-see-your-liked-posts\/\">likes<\/a>, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/07\/threads-expands-search-to-most-english-and-spanish-speaking-countries\/\">full-text search<\/a>, a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/25\/metas-threads-app-is-rolling-out-a-following-feed\/\">chronological feed<\/a>, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/12\/threads-is-rolling-out-an-edit-button-and-you-dont-have-to-pay-for-it\/\">voice posts<\/a>, and more. Given the rapid adoption, CEO Mark Zuckerberg suggested on a call with investors on Wednesday that Threads could be "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/zuckerberg-says-threads-has-a-good-chance-of-reaching-1-billion-users-in-a-few-years\/\">Meta’s next billion-user app.<\/a><\/p>\n Those projections are somewhat optimistic, given that Threads is now at just under 100 million monthly active users, as Zuckerberg also said. And they don’t take into account the surprising “stickiness” factor of X, which has "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/despite-usage-declines-x-remains-stickier-than-first-thought\/\">managed to retain its U.S. power users and increased the time spent<\/a> by its daily active users, according to at least one report, even though X has declined on other metrics, like "https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/tech\/xs-tumultuous-first-year-under-elon-musk-in-charts-71656f81?mod=followamazon\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">overall daily active usage<\/a>, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/17\/one-year-post-acquisition-x-traffic-and-monthly-active-users-are-in-decline-report-claims\/\">monthly usage, and website traffic<\/a>, as other research firms have found.<\/p>\n "attachment_2620605\" style=\"width: 1284px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2620605\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2620605 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-26-at-2.09.52\u202fPM.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1274\" height=\"750\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-26-at-2.09.52\u202fPM.jpg 1274w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-26-at-2.09.52\u202fPM.jpg?resize=150,88 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-26-at-2.09.52\u202fPM.jpg?resize=300,177 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-26-at-2.09.52\u202fPM.jpg?resize=768,452 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-26-at-2.09.52\u202fPM.jpg?resize=680,400 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-26-at-2.09.52\u202fPM.jpg?resize=1200,706 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Screenshot-2023-10-26-at-2.09.52\u202fPM.jpg?resize=50,29 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1274px) 100vw, 1274px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2620605\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> screenshot of Mark Zuckerberg’s Threads account<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n As Threads looks to find more ways to hook and engage users, it’s racing to add features that Twitter users have come to expect.<\/p>\n Polls, in particular, have been a popular way to boost engagement on Twitter\/X as they allow users who aren’t heavy posters to weigh in on a topic and have their voice heard. Those who post polls can attract new followers and take the pulse of a wide group of people without having to run a more formal survey. They can also be used for fun, like asking what to eat for dinner or which movie to see, among other personal questions. X owner Elon Musk, in fact, has regularly used polls to drive decisions about the company’s direction following the acquisition, like "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/19\/should-elon-step-down-as-head-of-twitter-users-vote-yes-by-a-margin-of-15\/\"> whether he should step down as the head of the company<\/a>, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/02\/elon-musk-nazis-kanye-twitter-andrew-anglin\/\">declare amnesty for banned accounts<\/a>, or "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/31\/elon-musk-vine-reboot-poll\/\">bring back Vine,<\/a> the short video platform "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2016\/10\/27\/twitter-is-shutting-down-vine\/\">Twitter killed off back in 2016.<\/a><\/p>\n On Threads, polls will run for 24 hours and you can control who can respond to the poll, the same way you can control who can reply to a post.<\/p>\n "attachment_2620616\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2620616\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2620616\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Polls-Asset.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"473\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Polls-Asset.png 9074w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Polls-Asset.png?resize=150,104 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Polls-Asset.png?resize=300,209 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Polls-Asset.png?resize=768,534 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Polls-Asset.png?resize=680,473 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Polls-Asset.png?resize=1536,1068 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Polls-Asset.png?resize=2048,1425 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Polls-Asset.png?resize=1200,835 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Polls-Asset.png?resize=50,35 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2620616\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Threads<\/p><\/div><\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n GIFs, meanwhile, remain of interest to online users as a whole, though "https:\/\/www.theguardian.com\/technology\/2022\/sep\/16\/gifs-are-cringe-and-for-boomers-giphy-claims-in-meta-takeover-filing\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">younger generations sometimes now see them as “cringe.”<\/a> Meta itself even "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/15\/facebook-to-acquire-giphy-in-a-deal-reportedly-worth-400-million\/\">acquired<\/a> the GIF search engine Giphy for $400 million in 2020, but was forced to divest of it due to an antitrust order from the U.K.’s competition authority.
"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/23\/meta-sells-giphy-to-shutterstock-for-53m-after-uk-divestment-order\/\">Shutterstock bought the site<\/a> in a deal that valued the company at just $53 million. Giphy, not surprisingly, powers the new GIFs option on Threads.<\/p>\n "attachment_2620615\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2620615\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2620615\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Gifs-Asset.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"473\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Gifs-Asset.png 9074w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Gifs-Asset.png?resize=150,104 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Gifs-Asset.png?resize=300,209 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Gifs-Asset.png?resize=768,534 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Gifs-Asset.png?resize=680,473 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Gifs-Asset.png?resize=1536,1068 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Gifs-Asset.png?resize=2048,1425 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Gifs-Asset.png?resize=1200,835 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Gifs-Asset.png?resize=50,35 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2620615\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Threads<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n While polls and GIFs aren’t the most significant features to add to Threads’ Twitter clone, they’re features that put the app more on par with X and ahead of some other would-be X rivals like the startup Bluesky, which does not yet support GIFs. (Though "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/12\/bluesky-gets-its-first-third-party-mobile-app-with-graysky-launching-later-this-month\/\">some of its third-party clients do<\/a>.) The features appear to be available on the Threads mobile app at present, but not yet on the web.<\/p>\n There’s much more Threads would have to do to make itself more of an X competitor, of course, beyond just cloning its features — which "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/25\/will-xs-addition-of-audio-and-video-calling-create-stickiness-in-the-app\/\">now include audio and video calls<\/a>, as of today. X remains a real-time news source and place to discover trends, both of which are a big draw. While Instagram head Adam Mosseri has said "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/11\/instagram-head-says-threads-is-not-going-to-amplify-news-on-the-platform\/\">Threads would not amplify news on the platform<\/a>, in its battle with X, Threads was "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/09\/instagram-threads-preps-a-trending-topics-feature-in-battle-with-x\/\">spotted developing a Trending Topics feature<\/a> that would make it feel more Twitter-like. It’s unclear when or if that feature will launch publicly.<\/p>\n Update, 7 pm et Later in the day, Instagram head Adam Mosseri posted that Threads would also begin tests of view counts and pinning posts or replies to your profile \u2014 also X features. He "https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@mosseri\/post\/Cy4PWLFPCMI\/?igshid=MzRlODBiNWFlZA==\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">wrote<\/a>, \u201cView counts are interesting as I think if we were shipping Instagram, or Facebook, today, we would probably have them. They give people a better sense of their reach, and generally more feedback is a good thing.\u201d<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"A3sKkDzYEe\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/25\/will-xs-addition-of-audio-and-video-calling-create-stickiness-in-the-app\/\">Will X’s addition of audio and video calling create stickiness in the app?<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Will X’s addition of audio and video calling create stickiness in the app?” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/25\/will-xs-addition-of-audio-and-video-calling-create-stickiness-in-the-app\/embed\/#?secret=clE6vkqMgA#?secret=A3sKkDzYEe\" data-secret=\"A3sKkDzYEe\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Meta’s X rival, Instagram Threads, is copying a couple more X features today with the launch of support for polls and GIFs. TechCrunch","inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/threads\/#primaryimage","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/threads-desktop-GettyImages-1524135861.jpg","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/08\/threads-desktop-GettyImages-1524135861.jpg","width":4000,"height":2666,"caption":"The Threads logo on a laptop arranged in the Brooklyn borough of New York, US, on Tuesday, July 11, 2023. Meta Platforms Inc.'s answer to Twitter Inc. has rocketed to 100 million users in less than a week, Chief Executive Officer Mark Zuckerberg announced on Monday. Photographer: Gabby Jones\/Bloomberg via Getty Images"},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/57505"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=57505"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=57505"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=57505"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=57505"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=57505"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2620432,"date":"2023-10-26T08:44:09","date_gmt":"2023-10-26T15:44:09","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2620432"},"modified":"2023-10-26T14:19:07","modified_gmt":"2023-10-26T21:19:07","slug":"despite-usage-declines-x-remains-stickier-than-first-thought","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/despite-usage-declines-x-remains-stickier-than-first-thought\/","title":{"rendered":"Despite usage declines, X remains ‘stickier’ than first thought"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Despite overall declining usage since Elon Musk’s acquisition, X’s hold on the microblogging market may be stickier than first thought. The app formerly known as Twitter saw its daily active users drop 16% in September, according to "https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/tech\/xs-tumultuous-first-year-under-elon-musk-in-charts-71656f81?mod=followamazon\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The Wall Street Journal,<\/a> citing data from research firm Sensor Tower. The firm also said that the average time spent daily per user also fell 2% year-over-year in the third quarter. However, another firm has a slightly different view on X’s metrics, finding that the time U.S. daily active users are spending on X has actually been growing, and the usage by X’s U.S. power users remains largely unchanged.<\/p>\n "attachment_2620474\" style=\"width: 1602px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2620474\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2620474 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Twitter-Elon-changes.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1592\" height=\"1131\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Twitter-Elon-changes.png 1592w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Twitter-Elon-changes.png?resize=150,107 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Twitter-Elon-changes.png?resize=300,213 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Twitter-Elon-changes.png?resize=768,546 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Twitter-Elon-changes.png?resize=680,483 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Twitter-Elon-changes.png?resize=1536,1091 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Twitter-Elon-changes.png?resize=1200,853 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Twitter-Elon-changes.png?resize=50,36 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1592px) 100vw, 1592px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2620474\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Apptopia<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Sensor Tower isn’t the only firm to point to declining usage. Another research firm, Similarweb, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/17\/one-year-post-acquisition-x-traffic-and-monthly-active-users-are-in-decline-report-claims\/\"> recently said X traffic and monthly active users were in decline.\u00a0<\/a><\/p>\n Though app intelligence provider "http:\/\/apptopia.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Apptopia<\/a> largely agrees with Sensor Tower and others that X’s daily active users have been falling, it sees that drop-off starting in May of this year. Downloads also started dropping when the "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/24\/twitter-has-officially-changed-its-logo-to-x\/\"> app rebranded to X in July<\/a>. But that could mean, the firm suggests, that the declining daily active user numbers are not necessarily related to the reduced retention of longtime Twitter\/X users, but due to a lack of new users coming on board because the Twitter brand name disappeared from the app stores. (Plus, when Instagram Threads launched this summer, it immediately started advertising on the term “Twitter,” further complicating matters.)<\/p>\n In other words, it’s not a “users fleeing” situation so much as it is a problem with new users backfilling the losses, post-rebrand.<\/p>\n Estimates from Apptopia also found that new rivals to X, like Threads, aren’t necessarily wooing users away from one app to the other. In fact, the overlap between the two apps is lower than you might think. Over a month after Threads’ launch, only 10% of X users had tried out Instagram’s new Twitter competitor, and that figure dropped to 5% shortly after the app’s release.<\/p>\n "attachment_2620476\" style=\"width: 2470px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2620476\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2620476 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/x-and-threads-overlap.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"2460\" height=\"1116\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/x-and-threads-overlap.jpg 2460w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/x-and-threads-overlap.jpg?resize=150,68 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/x-and-threads-overlap.jpg?resize=300,136 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/x-and-threads-overlap.jpg?resize=768,348 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/x-and-threads-overlap.jpg?resize=680,308 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/x-and-threads-overlap.jpg?resize=1536,697 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/x-and-threads-overlap.jpg?resize=2048,929 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/x-and-threads-overlap.jpg?resize=1200,544 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/x-and-threads-overlap.jpg?resize=50,23 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2460px) 100vw, 2460px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2620476\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Apptopia<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n But what’s interesting here is that even when Threads was able to get X users to try it, X’s daily active users would spend more time on X than on Threads.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/05\/threads-passes-2-million-downloads-in-2-hours\/\">At launch,<\/a> Threads was initially competing fairly well against X, as Threads users who also used X were spending 23.8 minutes on the Instagram Threads app, compared with 31.1 minutes on X. However, as of September, those numbers have shifted. Now, users of both apps spend 3.7 minutes on Threads versus 16.9 minutes on X. That indicates X is retaining some of its pull, even as Meta announces that Threads is "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/zuckerberg-says-threads-has-a-good-chance-of-reaching-1-billion-users-in-a-few-years\/\">nearing 100 million monthly active users<\/a>.<\/p>\n Meanwhile, X’s U.S. power users — or those who are in the top decile of usage in the given time period — are still heavily engaged with X, Appotopia’s data found. This group now accounts for 72.4% of the total time spent among X users in the U.S., only slightly down from 73.1% in January 2022.<\/p>\n In other words, the percentage of total time spent that U.S. power users are responsible for hasn’t significantly changed since either Musk taking over Twitter or its subsequent rebranding to X.<\/p>\n In addition, X’s U.S. daily active users were spending, on average, 18.8 minutes per day on Twitter\/X as of January 2022. When Threads launched in July, they continued to spend 19.8 minutes on X. And as of September 2023, that number grew once again to 20.6 minutes.<\/p>\n Though overall, X may be seeing some declines, this “stickiness” factor around X usage has already caused its first casualty among would-be rivals. A startup called Pebble (formerly T2) that tried to take on X by copying Twitter features "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/24\/pebble-the-twitter-alternative-previously-known-as-t2-is-closing-down\/\">announced this week that it would shut down<\/a>, citing the competitive environment.<\/p>\n \u201cThe durability of the network effect of Twitter is stronger than anticipated,” noted Pebble CTO Michael Greer at the time. The founders also pointed to a landscape littered with Twitter clones angling for attention.<\/p>\n Given these new findings, Threads may still have a shot at competing with X because of its tight integration with Instagram and the resources of Meta behind it to grow an independent user base, but other X rivals like Spill, Spoutible, Bluesky, Mastodon and others may find it hard to convince X users to fully disengage to join their app instead.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"4oZcWoNJpm\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/24\/pebble-the-twitter-alternative-previously-known-as-t2-is-closing-down\/\">Pebble, the Twitter alternative previously known as T2, is shutting down<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Pebble, the Twitter alternative previously known as T2, is shutting down” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/24\/pebble-the-twitter-alternative-previously-known-as-t2-is-closing-down\/embed\/#?secret=AqYbUF9rGT#?secret=4oZcWoNJpm\" data-secret=\"4oZcWoNJpm\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"hwsJ09RKMQ\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/17\/one-year-post-acquisition-x-traffic-and-monthly-active-users-are-in-decline-report-claims\/\">One year post-acquisition, X traffic and monthly active users are in decline, report claims<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute;
