and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/1700"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=1700"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=1700"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=1700"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=1700"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=1700"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2620395,"date":"2023-10-26T07:44:22","date_gmt":"2023-10-26T14:44:22","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2620395"},"modified":"2023-10-26T13:55:00","modified_gmt":"2023-10-26T20:55:00","slug":"luminar-neo-brings-generative-ai-tools-to-hobbyist-photographers","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/26\/luminar-neo-brings-generative-ai-tools-to-hobbyist-photographers\/","title":{"rendered":"Luminar Neo brings generative AI tools to hobbyist photographers"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">While Adobe is bringing "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/13\/adobes-firefly-generative-ai-models-are-now-generally-available-get-pricing-plans\/\">generative AI models<\/a> to professional photographers and designers, another company is working to make easy-to-use generative AI tools available to a wider range of photographers, including hobbyists. Starting today, "https:\/\/skylum.com\/luminar\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Luminar Neo<\/a>, the photo-editing software from "https:\/\/skylum.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Skylum<\/a> (formerly Macphun), is rolling out a set of generative AI features to its desktop apps for Mac and Windows that will allow users to remove unwanted objects from their images, expand a canvas or replace and add specific elements into a photo.<\/p>\n The tools are similar in some ways to Google Photos’ Magic Editor and Magic Eraser or Adobe’s own Generative Fill tool. The difference between Adobe’s Generative Fill is that Luminar Neo offers two tools, GenErase and GenSwap, instead of one. It also doesn’t require the use of a text prompt field. Instead, the user selects an area on the image to remove and clicks “Erase.” But unlike Adobe’s Generative Fill, it doesn’t offer result options to choose from — the user would have to click the “Erase” button again to get a different outcome.<\/p>\n Founded in 2008 as Macphun by game developers and amateur photographers Paul Muzok and Dima Sytnik, the company now known as Skylum originally focused on iOS applications, like Vintage Video Maker, which Apple recognized among the best apps of the year in 2009.<\/p>\n The team then proceeded to develop around 60 other iOS apps over the years that followed, but were always drawn to photography. That eventually led the team to launch their first Mac app, FX Photo Studio Pro in 2010, which topped 50 million downloads. On Mac, they also launched other image-editing apps like Snapheal, Intensify, Tonality, Noiseless, Aurora HDR, then later merged several apps to make "https:\/\/skylum.com\/creativekit\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Creative Kit<\/a>. Photo-editing software Luminar came about in 2016. And in 2018, when they also rebranded as Skylum, the team began to focus only on their Luminar project.<\/p>\n "attachment_2620414\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2620414\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2620414\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-srafa-prada-2.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"408\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-srafa-prada-2.png 2000w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-srafa-prada-2.png?resize=150,90 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-srafa-prada-2.png?resize=300,180 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-srafa-prada-2.png?resize=768,461 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-srafa-prada-2.png?resize=680,408 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-srafa-prada-2.png?resize=1536,922 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-srafa-prada-2.png?resize=1200,720 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-srafa-prada-2.png?resize=50,30 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2620414\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Skylum<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n The idea with Luminar was to create photo editing software for desktop users that lets you perform complex tasks in simple ways. The latest version of this app was launched in "https:\/\/skylum.com\/luminar\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> 2022 as Luminar Neo<\/a>, and its user base is primarily hobbyist photographers. But a handful of professionals use the app, as well, the company says. For example, some commercial photographers tend to use Luminar Neo more as a plug-in for Lightroom or Photoshop, they note.<\/p>\n With the rise of generative AI models for image editing, the team knew they wanted to incorporate this functionality into the product to make editing photos even easier. The plan is to release one generative AI tool each month through the end of 2023, starting with GenErase on October 26.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n GenSwap (to replace elements) and GenExpand (to expand the canvas) will arrive on November 16 and December 14, respectively.<\/p>\n "attachment_2620415\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2620415\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2620415\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-WEAD-1.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"408\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-WEAD-1.png 2000w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-WEAD-1.png?resize=150,90 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-WEAD-1.png?resize=300,180 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-WEAD-1.png?resize=768,461 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-WEAD-1.png?resize=680,408 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-WEAD-1.png?resize=1536,922 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-WEAD-1.png?resize=1200,720 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-WEAD-1.png?resize=50,30 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2620415\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Skylum<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n “All three generative features that will be released this year are based on the same technology, but combining and changing the parameters gives us different results and covers different use cases for the end user, which is why we decided to have three separate features,” explains Ivan Kutanin, the Ukraine-based CEO of Skylum, in an email interview with TechCrunch.<\/p>\n The models are based on Stable Diffusion, but Kutanin says the company also uses its own Upscale AI model and others in a single pipeline, which allows the software to increase the resolution and quality of the generated images. Currently, it offers up to 1536×1536 in image resolution, he says. For comparison, Photoshop "https:\/\/community.adobe.com\/t5\/photoshop-beta-discussions\/generative-fill-produces-blurry-results\/m-p\/13830742\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">currently<\/a> offers a resolution of 1024×1024.<\/p>\n The processing itself takes place in the cloud, so the app requires an internet connection to work. However, the company doesn’t store either the input or output images to protect customer privacy.<\/p>\n The ease of use is what the company hopes will set its software apart from others that offer similar generative AI tools.<\/p>\n "attachment_2620412\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2620412\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2620412\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-ryoji-iwata-2.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"408\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-ryoji-iwata-2.png 2000w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-ryoji-iwata-2.png?resize=150,90 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-ryoji-iwata-2.png?resize=300,180 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-ryoji-iwata-2.png?resize=768,461 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-ryoji-iwata-2.png?resize=680,408 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-ryoji-iwata-2.png?resize=1536,922 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-ryoji-iwata-2.png?resize=1200,720 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/GenErase-c-ryoji-iwata-2.png?resize=50,30 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2620412\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Skylum<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n “Luminar Neo is the latest-generation photo-editing software and has around 40 complex AI models as part of its architecture, which makes it truly powerful. What we\u2019re best known for is the ease of use and how effortless it is to start out if you\u2019re a complete beginner,” says Kutanin. “Since a huge part of our user base are photography enthusiasts, we really focused on the user interface and making it as pleasant and fresh as possible,” he adds.<\/p>\n The software is offered at multiple pricing tiers for both new and existing users. After October 28, it’s either $14.95 per month, $119 per year or $179 for two years. A lifetime pass is available for $299, which comes with a “Creative Journey Pass” that has time limits on the new generative AI features through August 16, 2024. After that point, they need to purchase a new Creative Journey Pass or switch to a subscription.<\/p>\n For current users, the upgrade is slightly less expensive, with the one-year plan starting at $79 for year one, then $99 per year going forward, also after October 28. There are other discounts available if bought prior to October 28.<\/p>\n The company has never raised outside funding and has been profitable for a few years now, employing a team of more than120.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" While Adobe is bringing generative AI models to professional photographers and designers, another company is working to make easy-to-use generative AI tools available to a wider range of photographers, including hobbyists. Starting today, Luminar Neo, the photo-editing software from Skylum (formerly Macphun), is rolling out a set of generative AI features to its desktop apps k":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/25\/google-plays-policy-update-cracks-down-on-offensive-ai-apps-disruptive-notifications\/","title":{"rendered":"Google Play’s policy update cracks down on ‘offensive’ AI apps, disruptive notifications"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Google is taking aim at potentially problematic generative AI apps with a new policy, to be enforced starting early next year, that will require developers of Android applications published on its Play Store to offer the ability to report or flag offensive AI-generated content. The new policy will insist that flagging and reporting can be done in-app and developers should use the report to inform their own approaches to filtering and moderation, the company says.<\/p>\n The change to the policy follows an explosion of AI-generated apps, some of which where users tricked the apps into creating NSFW imagery, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/06\/lensa-goes-nsfw\/\">as with Lensa last year.<\/a> Others, meanwhile, have more subtle issues. For instance, an app "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/20\/remini-tops-the-app-store-for-its-viral-ai-headshots-but-its-body-edits-go-too-far-some-say\/\">that went viral this summer for AI headshots<\/a>, Remini, was found to be "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/20\/remini-tops-the-app-store-for-its-viral-ai-headshots-but-its-body-edits-go-too-far-some-say\/\">greatly enhancing the size of some women’s breasts<\/a> or cleavage, and thinning them. Then there were the more recent issues with Microsoft’s and Meta’s AI tools, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/06\/facebook-ai-stickers-bing-image-creator-jailbreak-guardrails\/\">where people found ways to bypass the guardrails<\/a> to make images like Sonic the Hedgehog pregnant or fictional characters doing 9\/11.<\/p>\n Of course, there are even more serious concerns around the use of AI image generators, as pedophiles were "https:\/\/www.theguardian.com\/society\/2023\/sep\/12\/paedophiles-using-open-source-ai-to-create-child-sexual-abuse-content-says-watchdog\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">discovered using open source AI tools<\/a> to "https:\/\/www.theguardian.com\/technology\/2023\/oct\/25\/ai-created-child-sexual-abuse-images-threaten-overwhelm-internet\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">create child sexual abuse material<\/a> (CSAM) at scale. And with the coming elections, there are also concerns around using AI to create fake images, aka deepfakes, to mislead or misinform the voting public.<\/p>\n "attachment_2619743\" style=\"width: 379px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2619743\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"vertical size-large wp-image-2619743\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/ai-art-generator-generic.gif?w=369\" alt=\"\" width=\"369\" height=\"680\" \/> "caption-attachment-2619743\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Google<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n The text of the new policy indicates that examples of AI-generated content includes “text\u2013to-text conversational generative AI chatbots, in which interacting with the chatbot is a central feature of the app,” which encompass apps like ChatGPT, as well as apps where images are “generated by AI based on text, image, or voice prompts.”<\/p>\n Google, in its "https:\/\/android-developers.googleblog.com\/2023\/10\/announcing-policy-updates-to-support-app-quality-on-google-play.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">announcement<\/a>, reminded developers that all apps, including AI content generators, must comply with its existing developer policies, which prohibit "https:\/\/support.google.com\/googleplay\/android-developer\/topic\/9877466\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">restricted<\/a> content like "https:\/\/support.google.com\/googleplay\/android-developer\/answer\/9878809\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">CSAM<\/a> and others that "https:\/\/support.google.com\/googleplay\/android-developer\/answer\/9888077\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">enable deceptive behavior.\u00a0<\/a><\/p>\n Beyond changing its policy to crack down on AI content apps, Google says some app permissions will also receive an additional review by the Google Play team, including those apps that request broad photo and video permissions. Under its new policy, apps will only be able to access photos and videos if it’s directly related to their functionality. If they have a one-time or infrequent need — like AI apps that ask users to upload a set of selfies, perhaps — the apps need to use a system picker, like the new "https:\/\/android-developers.googleblog.com\/2023\/04\/photo-picker-everywhere.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Android photo picker.<\/a><\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n "attachment_2619742\" style=\"width: 379px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2619742\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"vertical size-large wp-image-2619742\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/images-android-download.gif?w=369\" alt=\"\" width=\"369\" height=\"680\" \/> "caption-attachment-2619742\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Google<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n The new policy will also limit disruptive, full-screen notifications to only those times when there’s a high-priority need. The ability to pop up full-screen notifications has been abused by many apps in an attempt to upsell users into paid subscriptions or other offers, when really the functionality should be limited to real-world priority use cases, like receiving a phone call or video call. Google says it will now change the limitations and requires a special app access permission. This “Full Screen Intent permission” will only be granted to apps targeting Android 14 and above that actually require the full screen functionality.<\/p>\n It’s surprising to see that Google is first out of the gate with a policy on AI apps and chatbots, as historically, it’s been Apple that issues new rules to crack down on unwanted behavior from apps, which Google then mimics. But Apple "https:\/\/www.cnbc.com\/2023\/03\/03\/apple-crackdown-on-chatgpt-apps-unlikely-new-rules-possible-later.html#:~:text=the%20App%20Store.-,There%20is%20no%20formal%20AI%20or%20chatbot%20policy%20in%20Apple's,specific%20guidelines%20in%20the%20future.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">does not have a formal AI or chatbot policy<\/a> in its App Store Guidelines as of yet, though it has tightened up in other areas, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/28\/apples-app-store-tightens-up-on-user-privacy-with-new-rules-for-app-developers\/\">like apps’ requesting data for the purpose of identifying the user or device<\/a>, a method known as “fingerprinting,” as well as on "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/07\/apple-updates-its-app-store-rules-to-crackdown-on-clones\/\">apps that attempt to copy others.<\/a><\/p>\n Google Play’s policy updates are being rolled out today though AI app developers have until early 2024 to implement the flagging and report changes to their apps.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Google is taking aim at potentially problematic generative AI apps with a new policy, to be enforced starting early next year, that will require developers of Android applications published on its Play Store to offer the ability to report or flag offensive AI-generated content. The new policy will insist that flagging and reporting can be app economy continues to grow, having produced a record number of downloads and consumer spending across both the iOS and Google Play stores. and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/32740565"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=32740565"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=32740565"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=32740565"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=32740565"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=32740565"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2619757,"date":"2023-10-25T09:00:31","date_gmt":"2023-10-25T16:00:31","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2619757"},"modified":"2023-10-25T16:17:14","modified_gmt":"2023-10-25T23:17:14","slug":"as-publishers-block-ai-web-crawlers-direqt-is-building-ai-chatbots-for-the-media-industry","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/25\/as-publishers-block-ai-web-crawlers-direqt-is-building-ai-chatbots-for-the-media-industry\/","title":{"rendered":"As publishers block AI web crawlers, Direqt is building AI chatbots for the media industry"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">A number of news and media publishers "https:\/\/digiday.com\/media\/a-symbolic-gesture-publishers-question-the-effectiveness-of-blocking-ai-web-crawlers\/#:~:text=A%20number%20of%20publishers%20%E2%80%94%20including,large%20language%20models%20(LLMs).\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">are already blocking AI web crawlers <\/a>from accessing their sites, worried about the impact on traffic when all their work is swept up into AI chatbot experiences. However, a startup called "https:\/\/www.direqt.ai\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Direqt<\/a> believes publishers should embrace AI chatbots — just on their own terms. The company, which has now raised its first outside capital of $4.5 million, offers media companies like ESPN, GQ, Wired, Vogue, Cosmopolitan and others their own customizable chatbot solutions that provide a direct connection to their audience, increased engagement with their own published content, as well as monetization via ads.<\/p>\n The startup was originally founded in 2017 with a focus on chatbot monetization, before turning more recently to AI. In its earlier days, the company had built out the ability to serve promotions and ads inside a chatbot experience, which it licensed to a larger customer in the U.S. In 2021, the team pivoted to start building a chatbot platform for publishers, still slightly ahead of the GPT wave and the rise of ChatGPT.<\/p>\n “Part of that was, candidly, us being a little bit early to the market,” remarked Direqt co-founder and Chief Commercial Officer Nick Martin. “Fortunately, things over the last couple of months have really broken the direction we did anticipate all these years,” he said.<\/p>\n "attachment_2619810\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2619810\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2619810\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Cosmo-chatbot.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"680\" \/> "caption-attachment-2619810\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Direqt<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n The idea was that the existing chatbot platforms that had been built at the time were originally created for other purposes, like customer service, and didn’t really meet the needs of publishers. So the team decided they’d take on the challenge of building a platform that could work for publishers.<\/p>\n The team also realized that about 10% of consumers’ time on mobile was spent on messaging apps, like iMessage, WhatsApp, Telegram, Messenger, Viber and others, and around 5.3 billion people around the world engage in messaging. Meanwhile, publishers were telling Direqt they wanted a direct relationship with readers, rather than having to rely on the ever-changing whims of Big Tech companies, like Meta and Google, which have been distancing themselves from the news business in recent years.<\/p>\n Meta, for instance, has been "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/05\/meta-to-deprecate-facebook-news-in-the-u-k-germany-and-france\/\">pulling news from its products<\/a> after "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/01\/28\/how-publishers-will-survive-facebooks-newsfeed-change\/\">adjusting algorithms<\/a> in ways that negatively impacted publishers, and "https:\/\/www.theinformation.com\/articles\/google-and-other-alphabet-units-laid-off-staff-as-industry-resumes-cost-cuts?rc=48qqgg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Google recently laid off a portion of its news team.\u00a0<\/a><\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n While the earlier chatbot product for publishers leveraged tools like NLP and AI, over the last 18 months, Direqt has enhanced the platform to support more capabilities, including those that rely on generative AI.<\/p>\n Publishers can choose to implement their chatbot in ways that fit their own business’s AI policy and strategy, whether that means simpler, non-AI chatbots that let users ask about stories their team has written; those where editorial teams curate the AI-generated content before it goes live; or those where AI could generate a quiz or a set of questions about the story, and so on.<\/p>\n "attachment_2619800\" style=\"width: 415px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2619800\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"vertical size-large wp-image-2619800\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direqt-App-Screen-Shot.png?w=405\" alt=\"\" width=\"405\" height=\"680\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direqt-App-Screen-Shot.png 6459w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direqt-App-Screen-Shot.png?resize=89,150 89w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direqt-App-Screen-Shot.png?resize=179,300 179w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direqt-App-Screen-Shot.png?resize=768,1288 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direqt-App-Screen-Shot.png?resize=405,680 405w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direqt-App-Screen-Shot.png?resize=916,1536 916w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direqt-App-Screen-Shot.png?resize=1221,2048 1221w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direqt-App-Screen-Shot.png?resize=715,1200 715w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direqt-App-Screen-Shot.png?resize=30,50 30w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 405px) 100vw, 405px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2619800\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Direqt<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Or, if the publisher simply wants their own version of ChatGPT, that’s also possible, as Direqt works with OpenAI and other AI vendors, including Google, to meet the publishers’ goals.<\/p>\n The generative AI experiences have the most draw at present, even though some publishers may not have yet finalized their AI strategy.<\/p>\n “Almost everyone that we work with is trying to figure out their generative AI strategy if they haven’t already started deploying things,” says Martin. “There’s been a really fast-paced development in the perspectives around it since November 30 of last year to about 12 months later…we haven’t met a publisher yet, who’s like ‘we don’t want to do this,'” he says.<\/p>\n In fact, publishers may even be fighting some AI battles — like suing AI companies for aggregating their content into their models without permission — even as they move forward with their own bots.<\/p>\n “There doesn’t seem to be much of a sense of like, we’re scared of this technology and we don’t want to use it,” Martin continues. “There’s certainly a fear and a concern around AI through a few lenses — what it’s going to do to traffic from search, what is the impact on the creative and writers and journalism — and those two things are pretty massive. But it does seem that in all of the private conversations, everybody has a very sober view on the technology — [as in] ‘it’s not going back in the box, we need to figure this out.'”<\/p>\n As publishers are beginning to gear up for their annual planning, quite a few have plans to implement generative AI experiences in 2024, he notes.<\/p>\n "attachment_2619799\" style=\"width: 415px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2619799\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"vertical size-large wp-image-2619799\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direct-App-Screen-Shot-2.png?w=405\" alt=\"\" width=\"405\" height=\"680\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direct-App-Screen-Shot-2.png 6459w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direct-App-Screen-Shot-2.png?resize=89,150 89w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direct-App-Screen-Shot-2.png?resize=179,300 179w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direct-App-Screen-Shot-2.png?resize=768,1288 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direct-App-Screen-Shot-2.png?resize=405,680 405w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direct-App-Screen-Shot-2.png?resize=916,1536 916w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direct-App-Screen-Shot-2.png?resize=1221,2048 1221w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direct-App-Screen-Shot-2.png?resize=715,1200 715w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Direct-App-Screen-Shot-2.png?resize=30,50 30w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 405px) 100vw, 405px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2619799\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Direqt<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n To ingest publishers’ content, Direqt can leverage RSS feeds or, with permission, scrape the website.<\/p>\n The publishers’ chatbot experience itself can also be placed wherever the publisher wants, including directly on their website with a few lines of code, within partnered messaging apps that reach a collective 260+ million users. (Supported apps include Google Messages, SMS and Viber, with Messenger and WhatsApp to soon come.) And, later this quarter, social media will also be supported. In the case of the latter, Direqt is launching an integration with Instagram where users can comment on the publisher’s post, which will trigger the chatbot to initiate a conversation in Instagram’s DMs.<\/p>\n Today, the company has 75 brands on its platform, including names like Good Housekeeping UK, Women’s Health UK, ClutchPoints, Bob Vila, Dance Magazine, Hollywood.com, Indy100, Popular Science, The Drive, Domino, Field & Stream, Outdoor Life, Task & Purpose, Car Bibles, Popular Photography and others.<\/p>\n Within the chats, the bots serve links to publisher content, which see an average clickthrough rate (CTR) of 24.16%, compared with the average email CTR of 3.48% per active campaign. One customer, Mitch Rubenstein, founder of the Sci-Fi Channel and owner of Hollywood.com & Dance Magazine, said Direqt has boosted time-on-site by over 200%.<\/p>\n In addition to providing direct traffic, Direqt has a hybrid business model. Publishers can choose between a SaaS approach where it’s paid a platform licensing fee based on transaction volume, or a revenue-based model where Direqt takes a cut of the in-chat ad revenue that runs inside the platform. Those ads can be sold by the publishers or can include ads from Direqt’s 500 advertiser partners and other partners.<\/p>\n For publishers dependent on ad revenue, chat appears to be a good solution.<\/p>\n “There’s market data that suggests performance in chat is significantly higher to the order of 10% and 10x, depending on which source you’re looking at, that in-chat ads outperform traditional advertising,” Martin notes.<\/p>\n In addition to "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/nickmartindqt\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Martin<\/a>, formerly the co-founder and COO of a sports equipment manufacturer, Direqt was co-founded by serial entrepreneur "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/johnduffy3cinteractive\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">John Duffy<\/a>, a co-founder of another chatbot company 3Cinteractive; "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/mykwillis\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Myk Willis<\/a>, a former Citrix engineer, and co-founder and CEO of streaming radio company "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Myxer\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Myxer<\/a>; and "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/billmadden\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Bill Madden<\/a>, a former IBM product engineer.<\/p>\n The team has now raised its first round of capital, a seed round of $4.5 million from investors including various entrepreneurs and executives, including Todd Parker, former global head of Business Development for Business Messaging at Google; NFL Hall of Famer Dan Marino; Peter Callahan, former CEO of American Media; Ron Antevy, founder & CEO e-Builder; and Dave Walsh, partner at Kayne Anderson.<\/p>\n The funds will help Direqt accelerate product development, roadmap and go-to-market, and allow it to double its headcount from 15 to about 30 people by the end of next year. The Seattle-headquartered company aims to improve the core conversational engine it offers, increasing its monetization capabilities and unlocking more distribution with the new funds, as well.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" A number of news and media publishers are already blocking AI web crawlers from accessing their sites, worried about the impact on traffic when all their work is swept up into AI chatbot experiences. However, a startup called Direqt believes publishers should embrace AI chatbots — just on their own terms. The company, which has | TechCrunch","description":"Read the latest news about Startups on TechCrunch","canonical":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/","next":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/page\/2\/","og_locale":"en_US","og_type":"article","og_title":"Startups | TechCrunch","og_description":"Read the latest news about Startups on TechCrunch","og_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/","og_site_name":"TechCrunch","og_image":[{"width":1200,"height":1200,"url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","type":"image\/png"}],"twitter_card":"summary_large_image","twitter_site":"@TechCrunch","schema":{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@graph":[{"@type":"CollectionPage","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/","name":"Startups | TechCrunch","isPartOf":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website"},"primaryImageOfPage":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/#primaryimage"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/#primaryimage"},"thumbnailUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/08\/Bletchley_Park_Mansion.jpg","description":"Read the latest news about Startups on TechCrunch","inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/startups\/#primaryimage","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/08\/Bletchley_Park_Mansion.jpg","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/08\/Bletchley_Park_Mansion.jpg","width":1920,"height":1131,"caption":"Bletchley Park Mansion"},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/449557042"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=449557042"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=449557042"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2619137,"date":"2023-10-25T06:00:49","date_gmt":"2023-10-25T13:00:49","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2619137"},"modified":"2023-10-25T11:46:24","modified_gmt":"2023-10-25T18:46:24","slug":"amazon-brings-conversational-ai-to-kids-with-launch-of-explore-with-alexa","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/25\/amazon-brings-conversational-ai-to-kids-with-launch-of-explore-with-alexa\/","title":{"rendered":"Amazon brings conversational AI to kids with launch of ‘Explore with Alexa’"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Amazon’s Echo devices will now allow kids to have interactive conversations with an AI-powered Alexa via a new feature called “Explore with Alexa.” First "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/20\/amazon-introduces-new-echo-pop-kids-kids-tablets-and-a-family-friendly-alexa-experience\/\">announced<\/a> in September, the addition to the Amazon Kids+ content subscription allows children to have kid-friendly conversations with Alexa, powered by generative AI, but in a protected fashion designed to ensure the experience remains safe and appropriate.<\/p>\n Though there are already some AI experiences that cater to younger users, like the "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/05\/31\/character-ai-the-a16z-backed-chatbot-startup-tops-1-7m-installs-in-first-week\/\">AI chatbots from Character.ai<\/a> and other companies, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/27\/meta-mr-beast-paris-hilton-celebrity-ais-llama-2\/\">including Meta<\/a>, Amazon is among the first to specifically look to generative AI to develop a conversational experience for kids under the age of 13.<\/p>\n That also comes with constraints, however, as generative AI can be led astray or “ "https:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Hallucination_(artificial_intelligence)\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">hallucinate<\/a>” answers, while kids could ask inappropriate questions. To address these potential problems, Amazon has put guardrails into place around its use of gen AI for kids.<\/p>\n For starters, the Alexa Kids science team narrowed down the new experience, which leverages Alexa’s LLM (large language model) technology, to include only kid-friendly fun facts and trivia questions. Initially, the content will come from just two partners, the World Wildlife Fund and A-Z animals. In time, the team would like to expand the AI to include other areas of interest to kids, like space, music, video games and sports.<\/p>\n In addition, and perhaps most importantly, the generative AI experience is not happening in real time on the device.<\/p>\n “We want to go slow and be intentional and be measured with how we’re introducing this new tech, as well as any new tech for kids, which is why we’re not just hooking the experience up to an LLM at runtime and kind of letting kids go at it,” explains Arjun Venkataswamy, senior product manager for Alexa Kids, in an interview with TechCrunch. “The way that we’ve integrated an LLM here is we use it to generate content at scale offline, and then go through a review process that includes both humans, as well as AI, and then take that reviewed content and then put it into our experience,” he says.<\/p>\n In other words, kids aren’t using generative AI on the fly when conversing with Alexa, and the content is pre-reviewed and comes from a small dataset of just animal facts and sources.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n However, because the AI can generate tens of thousands of potential responses, not every answer can be reviewed by a human before being added to the experience. To that end, Amazon is also using AI to help it review the materials it’s using for “Explore with Alexa.”<\/p>\n “What our AI is doing is taking trusted content and then figuring out what’s fun, looking at what’s fun, turning them into a trivia question — so it is doing useful things for us at scale that we wouldn’t have been able to do without this tooling…but we feel really good about the safety guardrails that are in place right now in terms of content,” says Venkataswamy.<\/p>\n To access the new experience, kids can trigger the AI-generated facts or trivia in one of two ways. They can either utter a particular phrase that kicks off “Explore with Alexa,” like “Alexa, let’s explore animals” or “Alexa, tell me an animal fact.” But the more interesting way to use this feature is to have kids engage in organic conversations with Alexa where this topic could come up. For instance, a kid might ask “What does a lion’s roar sound like?” or “How fast can a cheetah run?” This would also allow kids to enter the more conversational Q&A experience.<\/p>\n Plus, over the next few months, Alexa will also prompt kids on some occasions, asking if they want to hear something interesting about animals.<\/p>\n Unlike more traditional conversations with Alexa, the AI experience works two ways. That is, it’s not just kids asking Alexa a question and receiving a response.<\/p>\n “One of the things we think is really cool about this paradigm is kids aren’t just asking Alexa questions and getting the answers — Alexa is now asking kids questions,” says Venkataswamy. That is, Alexa could ask the kids a trivia question like “What’s the fastest animal on Earth?”<\/p>\n As any teacher will tell you, by having the kids try to think of the answer first, the answer will stick in their minds better when they hear the response.<\/p>\n “Right now it’s, it’s narrow. Alexa is asking kids trivia questions,” Venkataswamy continues. “But we want to continue expanding on that and making it more interactive.”<\/p>\n Eventually, Amazon wants to have this generative AI experience integrated at runtime for both kids and adults, but it knows it needs to proceed carefully, especially with the former.<\/p>\n “We do want to integrate an LLM in runtime in a more protected way than we would integrate it for adults…However, this approach lets us iterate and figure out the right ways to get both safe and delightful content outputted from the LLM for kids,” says Venkataswamy.<\/p>\n Amazon is also preparing to launch an "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/20\/amazon-brings-generative-ai-to-alexa\/\"> AI-powered<\/a> “Let’s Chat” Alexa experience for adults later this year, he says.<\/p>\n In terms of privacy, the company notes it’s not training its LLM on kids’ answers. In addition, the “Explore with Alexa” experience and any future LLM-backed features will continue to follow the same data handling policies of “classic Alexa” (non-AI Alexa). That means the Alexa app will include a list of the questions asked by kids in the household (those with a kids’ profile) and the response Alexa provided. That history can be stored or deleted either manually or automatically, depending on your settings.<\/p>\n "attachment_2603356\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2603356\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2603356\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/amazon-tablets-kids.jpeg?w=680\" alt=\"amazon tablets kids\" width=\"680\" height=\"382\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/amazon-tablets-kids.jpeg 1534w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/amazon-tablets-kids.jpeg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/amazon-tablets-kids.jpeg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/amazon-tablets-kids.jpeg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/amazon-tablets-kids.jpeg?resize=680,382 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/amazon-tablets-kids.jpeg?resize=1200,674 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/amazon-tablets-kids.jpeg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2603356\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Amazon<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Alongside the launch of “Explore with Alexa,” the new "https:\/\/www.aboutamazon.com\/news\/devices\/new-amazon-kids-devices-2023-echo-pop-kids-fire-kids-edition\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Echo Pop Kids speakers<\/a> will also now be available for purchase, starting at $49.99 in the U.S.<\/p>\n The Echo Pop Kids will come in two new designs: Marvel\u2019s Avengers and Disney Princess, which feature corresponding character themes. Kids can use the devices to hear a greeting, fun fact or joke about an Avenger or Disney Princess, in keeping with the theme. Both also include six months of access to the Amazon Kids+ subscription service, which, in addition to “Explore with Alexa,” also offers a range of kid-friendly games, apps, books, videos and more, including custom Alexa themes.<\/p>\n However, you don’t need a specific “Kids” device to use “Explore with Alexa.” The feature works on any device set to kids mode or any communal family device, if parents have set up their kids’ voice ID.<\/p>\n Initially, “Explore with Alexa” will be available in English only but internationalization is further down the road.<\/p>\n It’s harder for Amazon to estimate when such an AI feature will become available at runtime for kids, though.<\/p>\n “I can’t give you a timeline, because we don’t have a concrete answer for what exactly we’re going to be doing yet, although we do have plans and experiments we’re planning to look into,” Venkataswamy says. “I will say that in terms of our criteria for when we’re going to get there, we’re working closely with the Family Trust team at Amazon that’s connected to a variety of research institutions in the U.S…we want to be able to get some confidence from external partners that our approach is right,” he adds.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Amazon’s Echo devices will now allow kids to have interactive conversations with an AI-powered Alexa via a new feature called “Explore with Alexa.” First announced in September, the addition to the Amazon Kids+ content subscription allows children to have kid-friendly conversations with Alexa, powered by generative AI, but in a protected fashion designed to ensure […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":2414667,"featured_media":2619408,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"abcdfde8-50c6-3be4-acf2-020d3d2ef6a9","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-25T13:02:22Z","apple_news_api_id":"800d2e1b-d0d6-4d84-80d5-605fe89c0001","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-25T18:46:33Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAQ==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AgA0uG9DWTYSA1WBf6JwAAQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577047203,449223024],"tags":[14067,153122,6602,12374,577122244],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n | TechCrunch","description":"Read the latest news about llm on TechCrunch","canonical":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/llm\/","next":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/llm\/page\/2\/","og_locale":"en_US","og_type":"article","og_title":"llm | | TechCrunch","isPartOf":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website"},"primaryImageOfPage":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/llm\/#primaryimage"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/llm\/#primaryimage"},"thumbnailUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1147500502-e1680624681276.jpg","description":"Read the latest news about llm on TechCrunch","inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/llm\/#primaryimage","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1147500502-e1680624681276.jpg","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1147500502-e1680624681276.jpg","width":2000,"height":1333,"caption":"gavel on open book"},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577122244"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577122244"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=577122244"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577122244"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=577122244"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577122244"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2618611,"date":"2023-10-24T09:00:41","date_gmt":"2023-10-24T16:00:41","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2618611"},"modified":"2023-10-24T11:37:23","modified_gmt":"2023-10-24T18:37:23","slug":"pebble-the-twitter-alternative-previously-known-as-t2-is-closing-down","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/24\/pebble-the-twitter-alternative-previously-known-as-t2-is-closing-down\/","title":{"rendered":"Pebble, the Twitter alternative previously known as T2, is shutting down"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">The grip Twitter, now called X, has on the market may be stronger than some believed. Unfortunately, that’s led to the first casualty among Twitter alternatives, as the startup "https:\/\/pebble.is\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Pebble<\/a> ( "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/18\/twitter-x-rival-t2-rebrands-as-pebble-saying-the-old-name-was-never-meant-to-be-permanent\/\">formerly T2<\/a>), is shutting down. The would-be X rival had grown a small but engaged community on its microblogging service that aimed to dupe Twitter’s features, from its "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/03\/30\/twitter-alternative-t2-launches-new-verification-program-hires-discord-engineering-head-as-cto\/\">\u00a0verification systems<\/a> to "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/31\/would-be-twitter-rival-t2-adds-dms-a-feature-others-including-threads-dont-yet-have\/\">functionality like DMs<\/a>. But the company says they’ve run out of time to make Pebble happen — the app maxed out at 3,000 daily active users, out of 20,000 registered users. That daily user figure fell to 1,000 daily users following its rebranding from T2.<\/p>\n In part, the sizable competition coming from other Twitter rivals was to blame, says co-founder and CEO Gabor Cselle, who had exits to "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2010\/02\/17\/google-continues-shopping-spree-acquires-remail-and-former-gmail-employee\/\">Google<\/a> and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2013\/03\/18\/namo-media-seed-round\/\">Twitter<\/a> prior to starting Pebble.<\/p>\n “I think the competitive landscape evolved faster than we had thought,” he explains. “I didn’t think that quite as many people — established organizations and newcomers — would try to do the same thing that we were doing and in very similar ways.”<\/p>\n Today, the market for Twitter alternatives is a crowded one, to say the least. There are numerous services for consumers to try, including the open source-based platform "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/24\/what-is-mastodon\/\">Mastodon<\/a>, a soon-to-be decentralized system from "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/24\/what-is-bluesky-everything-to-know-about-the-app-trying-to-replace-twitter\/\">Bluesky<\/a>, plus smaller startups like "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/16\/spill-twitter-alternative\/\">Spill<\/a>, Spoutible and "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/28\/post-news-twitter-alternative-a16z\/\">Post<\/a>, as well as "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/05\/threads-passes-2-million-downloads-in-2-hours\/\">a new app from Meta called Instagram Threads.\u00a0<\/a><\/p>\n Then, of course, there’s the X factor to consider. The default platform for short posts retains some pull, despite — or perhaps because of — new owner Elon Musk’s antics. Though the company may not have yet succeeded from a business and financial perspective, it’s been hard for others to duplicate its function as a breaking news platform and place for spirited debates.<\/p>\n “I think Threads and others have encountered this as well,” adds Pebble co-founder and CTO Michael Greer, previously "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/03\/30\/twitter-alternative-t2-launches-new-verification-program-hires-discord-engineering-head-as-cto\/\">Discord engineering head<\/a>. “The durability of the network effect of Twitter is stronger than anticipated,” he says.<\/p>\n "attachment_2601637\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2601637\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2601637\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/pebble-2.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"383\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/pebble-2.jpg 1600w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/pebble-2.jpg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/pebble-2.jpg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/pebble-2.jpg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/pebble-2.jpg?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/pebble-2.jpg?resize=1536,864 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/pebble-2.jpg?resize=1200,675 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/pebble-2.jpg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2601637\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Pebble<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Despite these challenges, Pebble initially had decent retention. By week four, it was seeing retention rates of 30%, in fact. Its invite list was also working, as 60% of people who received a Pebble invite converted to become users. In addition, some 10,000 users arrived at that list from early press, like TechCrunch’s coverage of its first outside funding — "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/12\/twitter-rival-t2-raises-its-first-outside-funding-1-1m-from-a-group-of-high-profile-angels\/\">a $1.1 million angel round<\/a> that included investors like former Google VP Bradley Horowitz, Android co-founder Rich Miner and the former CEO of Wikipedia, Katherine Maher. Data from "https:\/\/www.similarweb.com\/blog\/insights\/social-media-news\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Similarweb<\/a> indicates the Pebble website topped 99,300 visits last month, indicating repeat usage.<\/p>\n The company’s hypothesis was that consumers were hungry for a Twitter alternative that prioritized trust, safety and moderation from the start. To that end, Pebble’s founding team included co-founder Sarah Oh, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/25\/twitter-t2-human-rights-and-future-of-trust\/\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/25\/twitter-t2-human-rights-and-future-of-trust\/\"> Twitter\u2019s former human rights advisor.\u00a0<\/a><\/p>\n Pebble continues to believe its approach to moderation was correct, even if it was not ultimately a factor in driving growth.<\/p>\n “We came in with a particular angle: kinder, safer. Trust and safety. And I think our approach to moderation that we did have on the site did work,” says Cselle, adding that Pebble didn’t have some of the issues other federated platforms faced. For example, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/08\/blueskys-growing-pains-strain-relationship-with-its-black-community-moderation\/\">TechCrunch reported that Bluesky earlier this year<\/a> had strained its relationship with Black users, as it failed to crack down on bigotry on the site. Later, users on Bluesky were "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/17\/bluesky-racial-slurs-banned-list-usernames\/\">even creating usernames with racial slurs<\/a>, and yet the "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/07\/27\/bluesky-racism-slur-apology-feedback\/\">platform didn’t issue a public apology<\/a>. Pebble never faced any such controversies.<\/p>\n But it may have positioned itself a little too far into the “kindness” territory, the founders now believe.<\/p>\n “We were really seized by people saying they wanted something that felt safer, where they could speak openly without dogpiling,” says Oh. “And so we were confident that was an important thing to hit. Are there other things that are equally important and a great user experience? Yes.”<\/p>\n “Twitter is you have real people…saying real things,” Oh continues. “At the expense of using a word that’s overused, ‘authentic.’ And our theory was always if you can create a space where people really feel like they can let down their hair, then you would get that authentic content. We didn’t quite get there,” she admits.<\/p>\n Cselle agrees, noting that, perhaps, Pebble should have opened up enough space for disagreement to happen, while still drawing a hard line on the most disagreeable parts of running a Twitter-like platform.<\/p>\n “I think we could have maybe moved a little bit further towards that,” he says. “There’s a lot of nice things that are said on Pebble, but maybe not enough breaking news. Not enough conversation.”<\/p>\n There were other things that may have hurt Pebble’s traction, too, including its lack of a native mobile app. As T2, the startup prioritized building for the web to be agile and more flexible, but lost out on the opportunities for discovery driven by the app stores. Notes Greer, “that might have been a mistake.”<\/p>\n In retrospect, Cselle also questions if the "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/18\/twitter-x-rival-t2-rebrands-as-pebble-saying-the-old-name-was-never-meant-to-be-permanent\/\">rebranding from T2 to Pebble<\/a> may have been an issue.<\/p>\n “I’m wondering if the Pebble rebrand had actually softened the value prop[position] because T2 just encapsulated it so much — that it was really duplicative [of Twitter],” he says.<\/p>\n "attachment_2601624\" style=\"width: 2086px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2601624\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2601624 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/Screenshot-2023-09-18-at-9.22.20-AM.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"2076\" height=\"1410\" https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/Screenshot-2023-09-18-at-9.22.20-AM.jpg?resize=300,204 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/Screenshot-2023-09-18-at-9.22.20-AM.jpg?resize=768,522 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/Screenshot-2023-09-18-at-9.22.20-AM.jpg?resize=680,462 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/Screenshot-2023-09-18-at-9.22.20-AM.jpg?resize=1536,1043 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/Screenshot-2023-09-18-at-9.22.20-AM.jpg?resize=2048,1391 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/Screenshot-2023-09-18-at-9.22.20-AM.jpg?resize=1200,815 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/09\/Screenshot-2023-09-18-at-9.22.20-AM.jpg?resize=50,34 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2076px) 100vw, 2076px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2601624\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Pebble<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n Like most startup shutdowns, the answer as to “why” is not any one thing but a combination of factors. For Pebble, that’s certainly true. It was a perfect storm of competition, X’s continued traction, the lack of a native app, a brand that didn’t resonate and a space that was maybe a little too safe to be as addictive and as fun as the original.<\/p>\n With Pebble’s winddown, being announced to users today at 9 AM PT, early adopters will have the option of exporting their Pebble archive as a zip file that loads a mini web page showcasing all their old posts. Pebble won’t be directing users back to X however, or any other social network.<\/p>\n "attachment_2618840\" style=\"width: 2540px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2618840\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2618840 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Sarah-Perez-Pebble.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"2530\" height=\"1388\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Sarah-Perez-Pebble.jpg 2530w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Sarah-Perez-Pebble.jpg?resize=150,82 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Sarah-Perez-Pebble.jpg?resize=300,165 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Sarah-Perez-Pebble.jpg?resize=768,421 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Sarah-Perez-Pebble.jpg?resize=680,373 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Sarah-Perez-Pebble.jpg?resize=1536,843 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Sarah-Perez-Pebble.jpg?resize=2048,1124 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Sarah-Perez-Pebble.jpg?resize=1200,658 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Sarah-Perez-Pebble.jpg?resize=50,27 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2530px) 100vw, 2530px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2618840\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Pebble screenshot<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n As for where the founders will now hang out?<\/p>\n “I don’t know. Maybe LinkedIn,” Cselle jokes.<\/p>\n Pebble is also returning a small amount of the funds left over to its investors, more as a courtesy to show financial responsibility. The Pebble website will be shut down on November 1st and there aren’t further plans for the IP at this time.<\/p>\n The founders don’t regret their experience building Pebble, even though it didn’t turn out as they hoped, they said.<\/p>\n Says Cselle, “One thing that I learned is that there’s absolutely an audience that wants to see a new kind of Twitter-like platform built and will ask for the features that Twitter has.” He suspects the team might stay together to work on something new after Pebble wraps, taking the learnings from Pebble with them. That includes better communicating to users what great content should look like on a platform, and how they can win.<\/p>\n “We’re at an inflection point in social media,” says Oh. “We had one hypothesis with T2 and Pebble. It obviously didn’t pan out the way that we wanted it to. But I think we’ll look back and see this past year is a really important turning point for the role that social media plays in our lives,” she adds.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" The grip Twitter, now called X, has on the market may be stronger than some believed. Unfortunately, that’s led to the first casualty among Twitter alternatives, as the startup Pebble (formerly T2), is shutting down. The would-be X rival had grown a small but engaged community on its microblogging service that aimed to dupe Twitter’s […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":2414667,"featured_media":2601636,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"2556e35a-e4ed-3a2f-8e27-58cedfa7cc95","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-24T16:01:10Z","apple_news_api_id":"4ae426c1-3824-4f71-a5c1-dbddc0e1c4fe","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-24T18:37:14Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/ASuQmwTgkT3GlwdvdwOHE_g","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577051039,577055593,20429],"tags":[449557101,211367,915005,449557042,576602392,599182],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n Pebble, the Twitter alternative previously known as T2, is shutting down | TechCrunch<\/title>\n "description\" content=\"The grip Twitter, now called X, has on the market may be stronger than some believed. Unfortunately, that's led to the first casualty among Twitter\" \/>\n "canonical\" href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/24\/pebble-the-twitter-alternative-previously-known-as-t2-is-closing-down\/\" \/>\n "og:locale\" content=\"en_US\" \/>\n "og:type\" content=\"article\" \/>\n "og:title\" content=\"Pebble, the Twitter alternative previously known as T2, is shutting down | TechCrunch\" \/>\n "og:description\" content=\"The grip Twitter, now called X, has on the market may be stronger than some believed.
