on open book"},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/599182"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=599182"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=599182"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=599182"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=599182"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=599182"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2619099,"date":"2023-10-24T07:04:56","date_gmt":"2023-10-24T14:04:56","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2619099"},"modified":"2023-10-24T13:39:51","modified_gmt":"2023-10-24T20:39:51","slug":"wordpress-com-owner-buys-all-in-one-messaging-app-texts-com-for-50m","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/24\/wordpress-com-owner-buys-all-in-one-messaging-app-texts-com-for-50m\/","title":{"rendered":"WordPress.com owner buys all-in-one messaging app Texts.com for $50M"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">WordPress.com and Tumblr owner "https:\/\/automattic.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Automattic<\/a> is adding another company to its portfolio with today’s news that it has acquired the all-in-one messaging app "http:\/\/texts.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Texts.com<\/a> for $50 million. The app brings all your messaging apps together in a single dashboard, including iMessage, Slack, WhatsApp, Instagram, Telegram, Messenger, LinkedIn, Signal, Discord and X, with plans for more in the future, a "https:\/\/wordpress.com\/blog\/2023\/10\/24\/texts-joins-automattic\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">company blog post announced<\/a>.<\/p>\n Though other companies have tried to do something similar — like "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/21\/pebble-founder-launches-beeper-a-universal-chat-app-that-works-with-imessage-and-others\/\">Beeper<\/a> — Texts.com offers end-to-end encryption of your chats and other features users have always wanted, like the ability to schedule messages at a time that’s convenient for the recipient, not just for you. In addition, you can mark messages as unread even on services that don’t offer that feature, allowing you to remember to check that message again when you return, as well as get summaries of long group chats you’ve missed.<\/p>\n The company explained its interest in the messaging platform in an "https:\/\/wordpress.com\/blog\/2023\/10\/24\/texts-joins-automattic\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">announcement<\/a>, saying that the acquisition allows it to move into a “fourth market that’s integral to the modern web experience: messaging.”<\/p>\n Already, Automattic offers WordPress for online publishing, WooCommerce for e-commerce and Tumblr for blogging and a suite of ad tools. It also acquired a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/06\/14\/wordpress-com-owner-automattic-acquires-journaling-app-day-one\/\">journaling app, Day One, <\/a>and a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/07\/16\/tumblrs-parent-company-is-buying-popular-podcast-app-pocket-casts\/\">podcasts app Pocket Casts<\/a>, in 2021 and more recently, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/03\/13\/wordpress-com-owner-automattic-acquires-an-activitypub-plugin-so-blogs-can-join-the-fediverse\/\">an ActivityPub plug-in<\/a> that allows "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/11\/wordpress-com-blogs-can-now-be-followed-on-mastodon-and-other-federated-platforms\/\">WordPress blogs to connect to the wider web<\/a> of interconnected but decentralized social networking apps, like Mastodon, collectively known as the fediverse.<\/p>\n With the acquisition, Texts.com founder Kishan Bagaria will join the company as the new head of messaging, along with the rest of the distributed Texts.com team.<\/p>\n "https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2023\/10\/24\/23928685\/automattic-texts-acquisition-universal-messaging\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The Verge<\/a> first reported the news of the acquisition.<\/p>\n Speaking to "https:\/\/pca.st\/zkesr4d4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the Pivot podcast<\/a>, Automattic owner Matt Mullenweg explained that, in part, some of the desire for the deal was born out of personal frustration — everyone has multiple messaging apps, and it’s hard to track who you messaged on each one.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n “I found myself sort of getting very behind and so went out in the market and actually Automattic ended up making some investments in this space over the last few years, including in "https:\/\/element.io\/blog\/automattic-backs-matrix-investing-4-6m-in-new-vector\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Element, which is a Matrix company,<\/a> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/01\/21\/pebble-founder-launches-beeper-a-universal-chat-app-that-works-with-imessage-and-others\/\">Beeper<\/a>, which is another app, which has some similar things, but differently, and came across Texts, and was really just taken with the product,” he explained.<\/p>\n In addition, he said he likes to work in areas that you can spend the rest of your life on.<\/p>\n But Mullenweg also pointed to the current regulatory framework as something that made the deal more viable. With the EU regulations, he believed that it would be more difficult for Apple, Google and Meta to block a smaller player like Texts because it’s user-centric, runs client-side and is 100% encrypted.<\/p>\n “So it’s just as secure as their desktop apps,” he said. (Apple has fought against opening up its iOS platform to third-party app stores because they’re less secure than its own. It couldn’t make that same argument with Texts.com, apparently.)<\/p>\n According to Texts’ website, messages are never sent to its own servers — they’re sent directly to the platforms, which is how they’re able to preserve end-to-end encryption. In other words, they work just like the official apps do. Their servers also host no sensitive data, messages or account credentials, and all the data stays on your device.<\/p>\n Mullenweg also believes that putting a messaging app in the hands of a company like Automattic — a sizable company not considered a part of “Big Tech” — will allow it to develop Texts more quickly and maintain its focus. He suggested that big companies, like Google, often don’t get messaging right. (In fact, Google had "https:\/\/arstechnica.com\/gadgets\/2021\/08\/a-decade-and-a-half-of-instability-the-history-of-google-messaging-apps\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">so many different messaging initiatives<\/a> at one point, it became a running joke.) Plus, iMessage has been locked into the Apple ecosystem, which excludes people from participating if they don’t have an iPhone or Mac. U.S. teens, in particular, are locked into the Apple universe because of the blue bubbles, "https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/why-apples-imessage-is-winning-teens-dread-the-green-text-bubble-11641618009\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The Wall Street Journal reported last year.<\/a><\/p>\n The Automattic founder also said that Texts.com fits into the company because of its user-centric values tied to the way it tries to support everything people use for messaging.<\/p>\n “As users, we use all these things. And the companies want to pretend you don’t, but we all do. So that’s also something we’ve taken a big approach for…we just tried to integrate with everything. Open source also makes it easy, because people can write plug-ins for anything,” he said. “So I think if you keep those three things in mind, you can compete with the big guys, and in fact, thrive.”<\/p>\n Texts.com is "https:\/\/texts.com\/subscription\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">available<\/a> at $15 per month for most users, or $30 per month for businesses. It runs on Mac, Windows and Linux with apps for iOS and Android on the way. iMessage is only supported on Mac, and SMS only with iMessage. WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal, Messenger, Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn, IRC, Slack and Discord DMs are also offered.<\/p>\n "embed-youtube embed--youtube embed embed-jetpack breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"> "youtube-player embed-iframe embed-iframe--youtube\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/wT_jGLGTQ2c?version=3&rel=1&showsearch=0&showinfo=1&iv_load_policy=1&fs=1&hl=en-US&autohide=2&wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation\"><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" WordPress.com and Tumblr owner Automattic is adding another company to its portfolio with today’s news that it has acquired the all-in-one messaging app Texts.com for $50 million. The app brings all your messaging apps together in a single dashboard, including iMessage, Slack, WhatsApp, Instagram, Telegram, Messenger, LinkedIn, Signal, Discord and X, with plans for more […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":2414667,"featured_media":2619105,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"51eb5505-6ec1-333d-9cdc-de04ede5deec","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-24T14:05:02Z","apple_news_api_id":"bff4036e-8fa2-459f-b676-ec1421e78a70","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-24T20:39:55Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAw==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/Av_QDbo-iRZ-2duwUIeeKcA","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577051039,577055593],"tags":[142153,449557101,55574,18960,103613,108919,77847,577201586],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577201586"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577201586"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=577201586"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577201586"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=577201586"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577201586"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2618508,"date":"2023-10-24T04:30:46","date_gmt":"2023-10-24T11:30:46","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2618508"},"modified":"2023-10-24T10:08:27","modified_gmt":"2023-10-24T17:08:27","slug":"d-ids-newest-app-uses-ai-to-make-videos-from-photographs","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/24\/d-ids-newest-app-uses-ai-to-make-videos-from-photographs\/","title":{"rendered":"D-ID’s newest app uses AI to make videos from photographs"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">D-ID, the Tel Aviv-based startup best known as the "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/22\/a-i-creative-platform-d-id-the-tech-behind-those-viral-videos-of-animated-family-photos-raises-25m\/\">tech behind those viral videos of animated family photos<\/a>, is bringing its AI video technology to a new mobile app, launching today. Originally available as a web platform, D-ID’s "https:\/\/studio.d-id.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/studio.d-id.com\/\">Creative Reality Studio<\/a> allows users to upload a still image and script and then turn that into an AI-generated video. The technology can be used to create digital representations of themselves, historical figures, fictional characters, presenters or brand ambassadors.<\/p>\n Early use cases the company had been targeting involved corporate training and education, internal and external communication from companies, and product marketing and sales, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/09\/19\/d-id-the-company-behind-deep-nostalgia-lets-you-create-ai-generated-videos-from-a-single-image\/\">TechCrunch previously reported<\/a>.<\/p>\n Now available on mobile, users will download the D-ID app from the "https:\/\/apps.apple.com\/us\/app\/creative-reality-studio\/id6463755563\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">App Store<\/a> or "https:\/\/play.google.com\/store\/apps\/details?id=com.deidentification.studio\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Google Play<\/a> and then create an account or log in, if already registered. On the selection screen, you can either pick a premade “digital person” that D-ID provides or upload an image from your phone’s photo library. You’ll then enter the text you want the digital person to say, choosing from 119 languages, as well as pick between male and female voice options. You can also choose the tone of the speech — like cheerful, excited, friendly, hopeful, newscast, sad, shouting, terrified, unfriendly, whispering and others.<\/p>\n "attachment_2618603\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2618603\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2618603\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Appstore-1242-x-2208.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"192\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Appstore-1242-x-2208.png 11631w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Appstore-1242-x-2208.png?resize=150,42 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Appstore-1242-x-2208.png?resize=300,85 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Appstore-1242-x-2208.png?resize=768,217 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Appstore-1242-x-2208.png?resize=680,192 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Appstore-1242-x-2208.png?resize=1536,434 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Appstore-1242-x-2208.png?resize=2048,579 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Appstore-1242-x-2208.png?resize=1200,339 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/Appstore-1242-x-2208.png?resize=50,14 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2618603\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> D-ID<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n To work, D-ID is leveraging a mix of proprietary and open source AI technologies to power its platforms, says D-ID CEO Gil Perry.<\/p>\n “At its core lies a foundational model capable of generating video frames based on audio input. All its products are powered by its robust API with the ability to render video at an industry-leading 100 FPS, four times faster than real-time rendering,” he says.<\/p>\n “The core audience is AI enthusiasts, but it is relevant for anyone who wants to post videos featuring digital people, either versions of themselves or of anyone they can imagine – historical characters, fictional characters, ancestors, etc.,” Perry says. “The app enables video generation on the go, reducing the cost of production at scale, and allows the flexibility to produce videos anywhere.”<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n "attachment_2618604\" style=\"width: 393px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2618604\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"vertical size-large wp-image-2618604\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app1.png?w=383\" alt=\"\" width=\"383\" height=\"680\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app1.png 1080w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app1.png?resize=84,150 84w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app1.png?resize=169,300 169w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app1.png?resize=768,1365 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app1.png?resize=383,680 383w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app1.png?resize=864,1536 864w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app1.png?resize=675,1200 675w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app1.png?resize=28,50 28w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 383px) 100vw, 383px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2618604\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> D-ID<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n The videos can be up to 10 minutes in length and are subject to the same "https:\/\/www.d-id.com\/ethics\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https:\/\/www.google.com\/url?q=https:\/\/www.d-id.com\/ethics\/&source=gmail&ust=1697909788352000&usg=AOvVaw2djD4u-8MHRI2vTwN7NJiw\">\u00a0moderation<\/a> policies as the web version — meaning, the company is working to ensure the tech is not used for deepfakes that propagate misinformation and disinformation campaigns. The company has "https:\/\/www.d-id.com\/ethics\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">also pledged to respect copyright, adhere to AI regulations, and to not knowingly license its technology<\/a> to what it calls “contentious areas,” including political parties, pornography publishers, terrorist organizations, and guns or arms manufacturers.<\/p>\n Ahead of the mobile launch, the desktop version of Creative Reality Studio has seen 60,000 new sign-ups per day, with over 150 million videos already made using the platform, Perry tells us. In addition, the API for the service has more than 200,000 users.<\/p>\n With its arrival on mobile, D-ID is able to reach a broader market, including users who are mobile-first or mobile-only. This includes both existing users who are interested in using a leaner version of the studio for mobile devices as well as new users from the general public, including consumers.<\/p>\n "embed-youtube embed--youtube embed embed-jetpack breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"> "youtube-player embed-iframe embed-iframe--youtube\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/mE1puUGZgUs?version=3&rel=1&showsearch=0&showinfo=1&iv_load_policy=1&fs=1&hl=en-US&autohide=2&wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation\"><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n The new mobile service will be subscription-based, with plans starting at $5.99 per month. Users already subscribed to the desktop version can retain their existing plans. A 14-day free trial is also available.<\/p>\n Though headquartered in Tel Aviv, D-ID has employees in other markets around the work, allowing it to continue operations during the Israel-Hamas war.<\/p>\n “Our teams in Israel and around the world are working to ensure the highest level of support and service,” says Perry. “It should be noted that our team in Ukraine is operating with extra diligence out of high solidarity with the situation in Israel,” he adds.<\/p>\n "attachment_2618605\" style=\"width: 393px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2618605\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"vertical size-large wp-image-2618605\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app2.png?w=383\" alt=\"\" width=\"383\" height=\"680\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app2.png 1080w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app2.png?resize=84,150 84w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app2.png?resize=169,300 169w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app2.png?resize=768,1365 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app2.png?resize=383,680 383w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app2.png?resize=864,1536 864w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app2.png?resize=675,1200 675w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/D-ID-Mobile-app2.png?resize=28,50 28w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 383px) 100vw, 383px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2618605\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> D-ID<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n D-ID raised a $25 million Series B last year, following the launch of its Deep Nostalgia project and its spin-off, LiveStory. Those two projects involved animating historical photos of family members, with the latter adding audio. The "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/02\/26\/myheritage-now-lets-you-animate-old-family-photos-using-deepfakery\/\"> videos went viral<\/a> as people used the tech to create talking photos of long-lost loved ones or ancestors. Since then, D-ID has also been working to create a "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/03\/07\/d-ids-new-web-app-gives-a-face-and-voice-to-openais-chatgpt\/\">photorealistic interface for ChatGPT<\/a> as well as its "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/09\/19\/d-id-the-company-behind-deep-nostalgia-lets-you-create-ai-generated-videos-from-a-single-image\/\">Creative Reality Studio software<\/a>, as part of its broader AI development efforts.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"ONrIqUh8Wv\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/09\/19\/d-id-the-company-behind-deep-nostalgia-lets-you-create-ai-generated-videos-from-a-single-image\/\">D-ID, the company behind Deep Nostalgia, lets you create AI-generated videos from a single image<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/576596265"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=576596265"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=576596265"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=576596265"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=576596265"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=576596265"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2618456,"date":"2023-10-23T07:25:01","date_gmt":"2023-10-23T14:25:01","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2618456"},"modified":"2023-10-23T15:14:08","modified_gmt":"2023-10-23T22:14:08","slug":"household-restocking-startup-the-rounds-uses-tech-and-ai-to-make-sustainable-e-commerce-profitable","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/23\/household-restocking-startup-the-rounds-uses-tech-and-ai-to-make-sustainable-e-commerce-profitable\/","title":{"rendered":"How ‘household restocking\u2019 startup The Rounds uses tech and AI to make sustainable e-commerce profitable"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\"> "https:\/\/www.therounds.co\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The Rounds,<\/a> a sustainable “household restocking” service, wants to prove that last-mile logistics can be done both efficiently and profitably. Now, it’s claiming a significant milestone on the latter, as the startup claims it’s profitable not only at the unit economic level but also in terms of how it operates its fulfillment centers — the neighborhood locations from where it delivers inventory — like grocery items and household goods — and dispatches staff to fill customers’ orders.<\/p>\n “Being able to hit profitability there means the next step is true cashflow positive, and we’re making really good progress towards that,” The Rounds co-founder and CEO\u00a0 "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/atorrey\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/atorrey\/\">Alex Torrey<\/a> tells TechCrunch.<\/p>\n Launched in 2019 in Philadelphia, and now available in D.C., Miami and Atlanta, "https:\/\/www.therounds.co\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.therounds.co\/\">The Rounds<\/a> allows customers to shop from across 650 SKUs, up from 150 just a year ago. These cover a range of products, including household items, personal care, pantry staples and dry goods, in addition to items from select local sellers or co-ops, including bakeries, coffee roasters, florists or those who sell cheese, milk or eggs. In Miami, alcohol delivery is also available.<\/p>\n Customers sign up for the service, and for $10 per month, they can choose to restock their household’s needs — while also dramatically cutting down on plastic and packaging waste.<\/p>\n "attachment_2618555\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2618555\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2618555\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/NOW-SOON-LATER-3.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"680\" \/> "caption-attachment-2618555\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> The Rounds<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n That’s because The Rounds’ business model involves delivering your items in reusable bags and containers. So instead of receiving your Instacart order in a dozen plastic bags on your doorstep, you receive your order in reusable shopping bags or cooler bags for the cold items. In addition, the items themselves come in reusable packaging — like mason jars or glass soap dispensers, for example. When you’re out, you place those containers in the bag on your doorstep where it’s picked up, washed and then re-used for future orders. For instance, your glass soap dispenser is refilled at the local hub from 50-gallon drums, and then returned.<\/p>\n In total, around 70% of the products The Rounds sells are in reusable packaging.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n Since closing "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/06\/the-rounds-raises-38m-series-a-for-its-sustainable-household-restocking-service\/\">its $38 million Series A last year<\/a>, The Rounds has saved 375,000 pounds of packaging waste, Torrey notes. In addition, The Rounds’ revenue has increased 6x during that time, he says, as the service has become more efficient.<\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"lsdH3QvyTp\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/06\/the-rounds-raises-38m-series-a-for-its-sustainable-household-restocking-service\/\">The Rounds raises $38M Series A for its sustainable ‘household restocking’ service<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“The Rounds raises $38M Series A for its sustainable ‘household restocking’ service” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/10\/06\/the-rounds-raises-38m-series-a-for-its-sustainable-household-restocking-service\/embed\/#?secret=Ct9sRxobmG#?secret=lsdH3QvyTp\" data-secret=\"lsdH3QvyTp\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n “We now average between 15 and 18 deliveries per hour…that’s like UPS-level,” the CEO notes. This scale has been achieved, in part, by targeting specific urban ZIP codes where the service is accessible by 3.3 million households across its four markets, or a total of 8.6 million people. Within those ZIP codes, The Rounds targets apartment buildings to help it achieve density, making it easier to reach higher deliveries per hour metrics.<\/p>\n At present, the service has north of 10,000 paying subscribers — a figure that could be impacted by the service’s price.<\/p>\n “It is not the cheapest,” Torrey admits. “You can go to discount grocers or lower-price grocers to buy conventional goods that are lower in price,” he says. “But we’re also not a premium.” That is, The Rounds is not marking up items over retail to make ends meet, as Instacart often does. “We sell you premium products at the market price, no markup, and we bring it to you and put it in reusable packing.”<\/p>\n The longer-term goal is for The Rounds to get even smarter about what its customers need. This plan, which Torrey refers to as the “psychic home manager,” would eventually be able to determine what the customer needs to restock and when, so there’s no food and inventory waste, either. This part of The Rounds’ business could be aided by AI.<\/p>\n Already, AI is helping maximize the efficiency of The Rounds’ delivery routing and is now powering its recommendation engine that offers smarter suggestions of what to buy next, which helps increase average order value.<\/p>\n In time, AI should help The Rounds predict what the customer needs.<\/p>\n "attachment_2618476\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2618476\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2618476\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/the-rounds-items.webp?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"453\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/the-rounds-items.webp 1390w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/the-rounds-items.webp?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/the-rounds-items.webp?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/the-rounds-items.webp?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/the-rounds-items.webp?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/the-rounds-items.webp?resize=1200,799 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/the-rounds-items.webp?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2618476\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> The Rounds<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n “The idea of building your ‘psychic home manager’ has been like our North Star,” explains Torrey. And, he adds, “implicit in ‘psychic’ is AI — it’s how do we have a prediction engine?”<\/p>\n “In the beginning, we had very limited ability to make predictions, let alone use any kind of machine learning or sophisticated algorithms. We had very, very basic algorithms that were helping us make those predictions,” Torrey continues.<\/p>\n Since its Series A, The Rounds has 10x’d its ability to make predictions with more powerful algorithms and true AI, Torrey says. “We’re not there yet…but we’re much, much closer to delivering that ‘psychic home manager’ experience,” he adds.<\/p>\n The company has achieved its fulfillment level profitability milestone and revenue growth while keeping its team lean. Though The Rounds, like other startups, did conduct layoffs last year, impacting GMs in local markets and other organizational changes, the current team is less than 50 people. The team also includes delivery personnel who are not contractors, but full-time hourly employees with benefits.<\/p>\n The hope, Torrey says, is that The Rounds’ progress can drive more sustainable e-commerce.<\/p>\n "auto\">“Despite being "il\">the<\/span>\u00a0largest consumer spend category, e-commerce has been stuck\u00a0 "il\">the<\/span> last 30 years — Amazon started in 1994 — with last-mile logistics that still runs on a single rail with single-use packaging,” the founder says. “We\u2019re excited about proving that two-way last-mile logistics can in fact be done hyper-efficiently to be both profitable and good for the planet.”<\/div>\n "auto\"><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" The Rounds, a sustainable “household restocking” service, wants to prove that last-mile logistics can be done both efficiently and profitably. Now, it’s claiming a significant milestone on the latter, as the startup claims it’s profitable not only at the unit economic level but also in terms of how it operates its fulfillment centers — the […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":2414667,"featured_media":2618551,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"e03bf83d-159f-3a99-90b8-f56e28f875f6","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-23T14:25:09Z","apple_news_api_id":"bc78ce67-373b-47c6-b429-11b4622a333d","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-23T22:14:16Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAABA==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/AvHjOZzc7R8a0KRG0YiozPQ","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577052802,20429],"tags":[9881,449557042,4501,577069847],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n How 'household restocking\u2019 startup The Rounds uses tech and AI to make sustainable e-commerce profitable | TechCrunch<\/title>\n "description\" content=\"The Rounds, a sustainable "household restocking" service, wants to prove that last-mile logistics can be done both efficiently and profitably. profitable","datePublished":"2023-10-23T14:25:01+00:00","dateModified":"2023-10-23T22:14:08+00:00","mainEntityOfPage":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/23\/household-restocking-startup-the-rounds-uses-tech-and-ai-to-make-sustainable-e-commerce-profitable\/","@type":"WebPage"},"wordCount":938,"commentCount":0,"publisher":{"@type":"Organization","name":"TechCrunch","logo":{"@type":"imageObject","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/themes\/techcrunch-2017\/images\/logo-json-ld.png","width":"600","height":"60"}},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/THE-ROUNDS-9_27-BFURLONG6428.jpg?w=680","width":680,"height":453},"thumbnailUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/THE-ROUNDS-9_27-BFURLONG6428.jpg","keywords":["e-commerce","Startups","sustainable","the and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/577069847"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=577069847"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=577069847"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=577069847"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=577069847"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=577069847"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2617939,"date":"2023-10-23T02:00:58","date_gmt":"2023-10-23T09:00:58","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2617939"},"modified":"2023-10-23T09:26:00","modified_gmt":"2023-10-23T16:26:00","slug":"tinders-app-gets-more-social-by-letting-friends-play-matchmaker","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/23\/tinders-app-gets-more-social-by-letting-friends-play-matchmaker\/","title":{"rendered":"Tinder’s app gets more social by letting friends play matchmaker"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">Dating app users will often sit with friends as they swipe through their matches in order to gain feedback, or even hand over their phone and let their friends swipe for them. Now, that real-life experience is becoming a part of Tinder’s product, as the company today is introducing a new feature called Tinder Matchmaker where users can invite their friends — including non-Tinder users — to view and suggest potential matches.<\/p>\n The idea, the company explains, is to allow Tinder users to learn who their friends or even their family members think would be a good match for them, and it’s inspired by Tinder user data. According to a survey the company commissioned, more than 75% of singles said they discussed their dating life with their friends multiple times per month.<\/p>\n But the “matchmaker” doesn’t have control over the experience in terms of actually swiping left or right on the individual profiles as they would if you handed over your phone. Instead, the Tinder users themselves will be the ones who ultimately decide if they want to match or send someone a Like, just like in real life. Plus, the friend who’s weighing in on your matches won’t need a Tinder profile to do so. That means you can ask married or partnered friends to participate in the experience without getting them into trouble.<\/p>\n To use the feature, Tinder users can start a session directly from a profile card or the app settings. This provides them with a unique link they can share with up to 15 friends for a 24-hour period. Friends following the link can either log into Tinder or continue as a guest (after completing an age verification prompt and agreeing to terms) to start their session. They can then recommend profiles for the Tinder user in question, which the user can review after the session ends.<\/p>\n “For years, singles have asked their friends to help find their next match on Tinder, and now we’re making that so easy with Tinder Matchmaker,” noted Melissa Hobley, chief marketing officer at Tinder, in a statement about the launch. \u201cTinder Matchmaker brings your circle of trust into your dating journey and helps you see the possibilities you might be overlooking from the perspective of those closest to you,” she added.<\/p>\n The company also partnered with “Players” singer Coi Leray to market the new feature. In a new video, she’ll soon show off how the “friend test” feature works.<\/p>\n The introduction of the new feature comes at a time when some younger users, and particularly Gen Z, have tired of swiping-based dating apps, "https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/opinion\/articles\/2023-01-10\/tinder-dating-app-is-losing-users-steadily\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> including Tinder<\/a>, leaving the company to try to maximize its revenue with more exclusive pricing tiers — like "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/09\/25\/tinder-snobs-can-now-pay-499-per-month-to-be-matched-with-the-most-sought-after-profiles\/\">the $499 per month Tinder Select subscription<\/a> for elite daters. In its most recent quarter, Tinder parent Match Group said paying users "https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/technology\/tinder-parent-match-sees-third-quarter-revenue-above-estimates-strong-user-2023-08-01\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">across its portfolio fell 5% to 15.6 million<\/a>. And "https:\/\/www.pewresearch.org\/internet\/2023\/02\/02\/from-looking-for-love-to-swiping-the-field-online-dating-in-the-u-s\/#:~:text=Three%2Din%2Dten%20U.S.%20adults,report%20facing%20harassment%20or%20scams.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">a Pew Research study found<\/a> that dating apps overall aren’t gaining traction in the U.S., where three in 10 U.S. adults report ever using one — a share that has remained unchanged since 2019.<\/p> "piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n Instead, many Gen Z users are turning to "https:\/\/www.cnbc.com\/2023\/01\/24\/how-gen-z-is-turning-to-dating-apps-like-bumble-bff-to-make-friends.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">friend-finding apps<\/a> and "https:\/\/time.com\/6256719\/gen-z-instagram-dating-app\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">traditional social media,<\/a> "https:\/\/www.nbcnews.com\/news\/gen-z-organic-dating-instagram-rcna70459\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">like Instagram,<\/a> to make romantic connections. Meanwhile, startups — like "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/14\/video-dating-apps\/\">Candid, Ditto, IRLY<\/a>, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/05\/10\/snack-a-tinder-meets-tiktok-dating-app-opens-to-gen-z-investors\/\">Snack<\/a> and others — are testing the waters with video, leveraging Gen Z’s comfort with platforms like TikTok to transform dating apps into more dynamic and authentic experiences. Another cohort is using AI for dating or dating practice, like "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/09\/teasers-ai-dating-app-turns-you-into-a-chatbot\/\">Teaser AI<\/a> (now rebranded "https:\/\/apps.apple.com\/kw\/app\/mila-your-personal-matchmaker\/id6447713174\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Mila<\/a>) or "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/06\/07\/blush-ai-dating-sim-replika-sexbot\/\">Blush<\/a>, for example.<\/p>\n Tinder Matchmaker is launching today in the United States, Australia, Brazil, Canada, France, Germany, India, Indonesia, Japan, Mexico, South Korea, Spain, Thailand, United Kingdom and Vietnam, and will roll out to Tinder users globally in the coming months, the company says.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" Dating app users will often sit with friends as they swipe through their matches in order to gain feedback, or even hand over their phone and let their friends swipe for them. Now, that real-life experience is becoming a part of Tinder’s product, as the company today is introducing a new feature called Tinder Matchmaker […]<\/p>\n","protected":false},"author":2414667,"featured_media":2617952,"comment_status":"open","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"template":"","format":"standard","meta":{"amp_status":"","relegenceEntities":[],"relegenceSubjects":[],"carmot_uuid":"3276aa23-f33c-3c88-8f83-253eb7e0826f","footnotes":"","apple_news_api_created_at":"2023-10-23T10:01:15Z","apple_news_api_id":"0ce6fb86-7985-49d0-8007-4278cf406b5f","apple_news_api_modified_at":"2023-10-23T16:25:53Z","apple_news_api_revision":"AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAQ==","apple_news_api_share_url":"https:\/\/apple.news\/ADOb7hnmFSdCAB0J4z0BrXw","apple_news_coverimage":0,"apple_news_coverimage_caption":"","apple_news_is_hidden":false,"apple_news_is_paid":false,"apple_news_is_preview":false,"apple_news_is_sponsored":false,"apple_news_maturity_rating":"","apple_news_metadata":"\"\"","apple_news_pullquote":"","apple_news_pullquote_position":"","apple_news_slug":"","apple_news_sections":"\"\"","apple_news_suppress_video_url":false,"apple_news_use_image_component":false},"categories":[577051039,577055593],"tags":[14204370,7434380],"crunchbase_tag":[],"tc_stories_tax":[],"tc_ec_category":[],"tc_event":[],"tc_regions_tax":[],"yoast_head":"\n | TechCrunch","description":"Read the latest news about Tinder on TechCrunch","canonical":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/tinder\/","next":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/tinder\/page\/2\/","og_locale":"en_US","og_type":"article","og_title":"Tinder | TechCrunch","og_url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/tinder\/","og_site_name":"TechCrunch","og_image":[{"width":1200,"height":1200,"url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","type":"image\/png"}],"twitter_card":"summary_large_image","twitter_site":"@TechCrunch","schema":{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@graph":[{"@type":"CollectionPage","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/tinder\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/tinder\/","name":"Tinder | TechCrunch","isPartOf":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website"},"primaryImageOfPage":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/tinder\/#primaryimage"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/tinder\/#primaryimage"},"thumbnailUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1147500502-e1680624681276.jpg","description":"Read the latest news about Tinder on TechCrunch","inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/tinder\/#primaryimage","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1147500502-e1680624681276.jpg","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1147500502-e1680624681276.jpg","width":2000,"height":1333,"caption":"gavel on open book"},{"@type":"WebSite","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#website","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","name":"TechCrunch","description":"Startup and Technology News","publisher":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization"},"alternateName":"TC","potentialAction":[{"@type":"SearchAction","target":{"@type":"EntryPoint","urlTemplate":"https:\/\/search.techcrunch.com\/search?p={search_term_string}"},"query-input":"required name=search_term_string"}],"inLanguage":"en-US"},{"@type":"Organization","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#organization","name":"TechCrunch","alternateName":"TC","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/","logo":{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","contentUrl":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2018\/04\/tc-logo-2018-square-reverse2x.png?resize=1200,1200","width":1200,"height":1200,"caption":"TechCrunch"},"image":{"@id":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/#\/schema\/logo\/image\/"},"sameAs":["https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/techcrunch","https:\/\/twitter.com\/TechCrunch","https:\/\/mstdn.social\/@TechCrunch","https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/techcrunch.bsky.social","https:\/\/www.threads.net\/@techcrunch"]}]}},"_links":{"self":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags\/7434380"}],"collection":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tags"}],"about":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/taxonomies\/post_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/posts?tags=7434380"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_battlefield?tags=7434380"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc-media-gallery?tags=7434380"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_unified_video?tags=7434380"},{"href":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-json\/wp\/v2\/tc_video?tags=7434380"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\/\/api.w.org\/{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[],[],[],[],[]]}},{"id":2617983,"date":"2023-10-20T10:27:05","date_gmt":"2023-10-20T17:27:05","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2617983"},"modified":"2023-10-20T11:19:33","modified_gmt":"2023-10-20T18:19:33","slug":"tape-its-software-for-musicians-aims-to-delivers-studio-quality-noise-reduction-via-ai","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/20\/tape-its-software-for-musicians-aims-to-delivers-studio-quality-noise-reduction-via-ai\/","title":{"rendered":"Tape It’s software for musicians aims to deliver studio-quality noise reduction via AI"},"content":{"rendered":" "speakable-summary\">After Apple discontinued its Music Memos app favored by musicians for developing song ideas, a new startup called "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/08\/tape-it-launches-an-a-i-powered-music-recording-app-for-iphone\/\">Tape It stepped in to fill the void<\/a> with an app that leveraged AI to automatically detect the instrument and annotate the recording. Now that startup is taking the next step in its journey to improve the audio-recording process with the introduction of an automatic, studio quality noise reduction algorithm, also powered by AI, that works on any audio — not just speech.<\/p>\n The "https:\/\/tape.it\/denoiser\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">AI denoiser shipped this week<\/a> as a free web app, with a plan to license the technology to vendors in the future. It will also later be integrated into the company’s flagship Tape It app, the company says.<\/p>\n Founded in 2020 by musicians and friends "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/tcwalther\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/tcwalther\/\">Thomas Walther <\/a>and "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/jan-n-2559b2116\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/jan-n-2559b2116\/\">Jan Nash<\/a>, "https:\/\/tape.it\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Tape It’s<\/a>\u00a0initial focus was on an iOS recording app for musicians. Before creating Tape It, Walther had spent three and a half years at Spotify after it "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2017\/03\/07\/spotify-acquires-audio-detection-startup-sonalytic\/\">acquired his audio detection startup Sonalytic.<\/a> Nash, meanwhile, is a classically trained opera singer, who’s also a bassist and engineer. The duo were originally inspired to build Tape It because it was something they wanted for themselves as fellow bandmates that would be as simple to use as Apple’s Music Memos, but made more powerful through the use of AI.<\/p>\n The original version of the app was able to automatically detect the instrument, and then annotate the recording with a visual indication to make those recordings easier to find by looking for the colorful icon. Musicians could also add their own markers to the files, as well as notes, and photos to review later on.<\/p>\n The app has since gained traction with around 10,000 monthly active users, the company says.<\/p>\n But as Walther told TechCrunch at the time "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/08\/tape-it-launches-an-a-i-powered-music-recording-app-for-iphone\/\">of Tape It’s 2021 debut<\/a>, the team aimed to broaden their use of AI over time.<\/p>\n "attachment_2618062\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"> "caption-attachment-2618062\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2618062\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/denoiser-3-result.png?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"456\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/denoiser-3-result.png 3188w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/denoiser-3-result.png?resize=150,101 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/denoiser-3-result.png?resize=300,201 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/denoiser-3-result.png?resize=768,515 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/denoiser-3-result.png?resize=680,456 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/denoiser-3-result.png?resize=1536,1029 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/denoiser-3-result.png?resize=2048,1372 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/denoiser-3-result.png?resize=1200,804 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/10\/denoiser-3-result.png?resize=50,34 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/> "caption-attachment-2618062\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"> Image Credits:<\/strong> Tape It<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n That led to the startup’s latest development — an AI-powered denoiser they’ve been building over the past two years. The challenge with recordings, the company explains, is background noise. In order to reduce environmental noise and electrical interference, musicians record in studios and leverage complex software. Tape It wants to provide a more affordable alternative using AI. Their software automatically removes noise like hums and hisses, not only spoken word, with the goal of producing studio-quality results on songs, single-instrument tracks and field recordings.<\/p>\n “What we developed is we created an automatic version of the denoising software that you have been finding in professional recording studios in the last 15 years,” explains Walther.<\/p>\n To verify its results, Tape It is "https:\/\/tape.it\/research\/denoiser\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">releasing an academic study with a scientific listening test<\/a> that shows the software’s quality in competing with industry-leading denoisers.<\/p>\n In a video, the company explains that while speech enhancement systems have advanced significantly, they generally only work for speech and distort or corrupt music signals. Meanwhile, professional denoising systems require manual control of complex software by professional users. Tape It’s technology involves connecting a neural network controller to a signal processing-based noise reduction algorithm. This allowed for automatic denoising of general audio signals, including music. The company plans to present its work at the AES conference next week.<\/p>\n “The reason people haven’t automated those [professional systems] is because you can’t traditionally put them into a neural network…you can’t train such a system,” notes Walther. “We are actually the first ones to train such a system and that’s why we’re quite excited about this larger area.”<\/p>\n He adds that the academic community will most likely be less interested in the denoising product itself but more in how they managed to get it to work this way because of the implications it has for other applications of automating studio software.<\/p>\n Still, the denoising software already has some interested potential customers, including a large studio software vendor and a large hardware manufacturer. In those cases, enterprise pricing will be made available but for smaller startups, less expensive plans will be offered.<\/p>\n "embed-youtube embed--youtube embed embed-jetpack breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"> "youtube-player embed-iframe embed-iframe--youtube\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/vyQxEknv0Uo?version=3&rel=1&showsearch=0&showinfo=1&iv_load_policy=1&fs=1&hl=en-US&autohide=2&wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation\"><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n “Everyone is excited about AI being creative,\u201d said Walther, when announcing the news. “We are excited about AI solving boring problems. We take care of background noise, so you can entirely focus on the creative parts and write more songs,” he said.<\/p>\n AI technologies aren’t only being used to reduce background noise for musicians, of course, other companies are also turning to AI to create near-studio quality sound for podcasters too. For example, "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/10\/04\/generative-ai-removing-background-noise-from-recordings-is-just-one-of-the-new-tools-for-podcasters\/\">Podcastle just this month launched its Magic Dust AI<\/a>, a generative AI tool that eliminates background noise and enhances its dynamic range.<\/p>\n Tape It’s five-person team is based in Berlin, London, Los Angeles and Stockholm, and includes designer and musician "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/christiancrusius\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/christiancrusius\/\">Christian Crusius<\/a>, previously of the design consultancy Fjord, which was\u00a0 "https:\/\/newsroom.accenture.com\/industries\/communications\/accenture-completes-acquisition-of-fjord-expanding-digital-and-marketing-capabilities.htm\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-mrf-link=\"https:\/\/newsroom.accenture.com\/industries\/communications\/accenture-completes-acquisition-of-fjord-expanding-digital-and-marketing-capabilities.htm\">acquired<\/a> by Accenture. The bulk of the work on the denoising software was done by "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/christiansteinmetz1\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> Christian Steinmetz<\/a>, a PhD researcher in AI and audio.<\/p>\n The company is continuing to bootstrap, having previously turned down offers of funding.<\/p>\n “This is fundamental research and we just didn’t know how long it would take,” Walther explained as to why they went this route. “We thought it was a bit risky if you get an investor who isn’t that patient — [they’d push you to ] just take an open source model and move on. But we wanted to have a larger technological advantage,” he said.<\/p>\n The company is now considering raising funds and is having those discussions, given the pace of the AI market, but hasn’t made any formal decision as of yet.<\/p>\n "embed-youtube embed--youtube embed embed-jetpack breakout embed--video\" style=\"text-align:center; display: block;\"> "youtube-player embed-iframe embed-iframe--youtube\" width=\"640\" height=\"360\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/gRjxY7GTV6Y?version=3&rel=1&showsearch=0&showinfo=1&iv_load_policy=1&fs=1&hl=en-US&autohide=2&wmode=transparent\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" style=\"border:0;\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts allow-same-origin allow-popups allow-presentation\"><\/iframe><\/span><\/p>\n "embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n "wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"2xT5FiYAQu\"> "https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/08\/tape-it-launches-an-a-i-powered-music-recording-app-for-iphone\/\">Tape It launches an AI-powered music recording app for iPhone<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n "wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Tape It launches an AI-powered music recording app for iPhone” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/08\/tape-it-launches-an-a-i-powered-music-recording-app-for-iphone\/embed\/#?secret=4kB7bTXWan#?secret=2xT5FiYAQu\" data-secret=\"2xT5FiYAQu\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n <\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":" After Apple discontinued its Music Memos app favored by musicians for developing song ideas, a new startup called Tape It stepped in to fill the void with an app that leveraged AI to automatically detect the instrument and annotate the recording. Now that startup is taking the next step in its journey to improve the
